Release information and restrictions of Decentralized EWM on SAP S/4HANA 2025 

For a complete list of Q&A from the EWM community, please access this link:
https://answers.sap.com/tags/01200615320800000705

In case you do not find your specific question there, feel free to post your question via the following form:
https://answers.sap.com/questions/ask.html?primaryTagId=01200615320800000705

entry.title: Goods Receipt Reversal for External Procurement in EWM - SAP S/4HANA 2025
entry.content:
In this blog post, I would like to explain how to cancel the Goods Receipt after Final Putaway for External Procurement in Extended Warehouse Management, in addition to demonstrating the process steps for testing, we will also discuss about potential errors and current limitations.

This new Monitor Mehtod is available in both EWM deployments: Embedded and Decentralized.

Background Information:

With the new Method 'Reverse after Putaway' in Warehouse Management Monitor (i.e. As of SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS0), it is now finally possible to reverse a goods receipt for an inbound delivery/item in external procurement scenario (e.g. Purchase Order) in EWM, even if the Putaway Warehouse Task is already confirmed.

This gives the warehouse team more flexibility to trigger GR reversal at anytime when the error is observed maybe during picking, as long as the reference purchase documents are still exist in system (i.e. not Archived).

The new Monitor Method (Reverse after Putaway) can be found in the following nodes in SAP Warehouse Management Monitor report (/SCWM/MON):
- Stock and Bin -> Physical Stock 
- Stock and Bin -> Storage Bin -> Physical Stock


Figure 01 - Simple Inbound Process Flow

Prerequisites:

  • Completion Status (DCO) for delivery item to be cancelled must be equal to 9-Completed
  • Purchase document is not archived
  • Quality inspection document is completed (if exists)
  • Authorization object /SCWM/SLFU with the value RS for Reverse Stock from External Procurement is assigned to your user.

Configuration Steps:

This configuration step is only required in Decentralized EWM deplopyment.

- Allow Reversal after Putaway for Completed LE Delivery
Navigate to SPRO -> Extended Warehouse Management-> Interfaces->ERP Integration->ERP Integration for Decentralized EWM-> Set Control Parameters for ERP Version Control


Figure 02 - Set Control Parameters for ERP Version Control

Testing Steps:

NOTE: The following testing scenario has been executed on SAP S/4HANA OP2025 FPS00 with Embedded EWM.

Scenario: GR Reversal for Inbound Delivery with reference to a Purchase Order:
In this scenario we will post goods receipt for an inbound delivery created with reference to a purchase order, then we will trigger the goods receipt reversal for the received delivery item via the new Monitor Method (Reverse after Putaway) in Warehouse Monitor report.

1- Create Purchase Order (Tx. ME21N / App. Create Purchase Order - Advanced)


Figure 03 - Create Purchase Order

2- Create Inbound Delivery in Logistics Execution (Tx. VL31N / App. Create Inbound Delivery)


Figure 04 - Create Inbound Delivery in LE

3- Post Goods Receipt in EWM (Tx. /SCWM/PRDI / App. Maintain Inbound Deliveries)


Figure 05 - Post GR in EWM


4- Create Putaway Warehouse Tasks  (Tx. /SCWM/PRDI / App. Create Warehouse Tasks - Inbound Delivery)


Figure 06 - Create Putaway WTs

Hint: don't forget to take a note of the destination storage bin number, to use it later on during the reversal step.

5- Confirm Putaway Warehouse Tasks (Tx. /SCWM/MON / App. Warehouse Monitor)


Figure 07 - Confirm Putaway WTs

6- Reverse Goods Receipt in EWM (Tx. /SCWM/MON / App. Warehouse Monitor)
 - Navigate to Warehouse Management Monitor report -> Stock and Bin -> Physical Stock.
- Select the stock line and click on More Methods -> Reverse after Putaway.


Figure 08/A - Select Reverse after Putaway method

 - Ensure to enter the exact quantity to be reversed. 
- You need to enter Inbound Delivery and Item numbers as well (if not proposed by system, in case of multiple reference documents exist).
- Then click Post GR Reversal button.


Figure 08/B - Post GR Reverseal in EWM

Hint: Material Document year/number/item could be entered as well if desired.

- If goods receipt reversal is successful, then a Warehouse Task of category 6-Goods Issue Posting will be created.


Figure 08/C - WT for GI is created

7- Check Inbound Delivery in EWM (Tx. /SCWM/PRDI / App. Maintain Inbound Deliveries) - Optional


Figure 09 - Check Inbound Delivery in EWM

In EWM inbound delivery, Goods Receipt and Putaway statutes will remain Completed (no changes).

8- Check Inbound Delivery in Logistics Execution  (Tx. VL33N / App. Display Inbound Delivery) - Optional


Figure 10/A - Check Inbound Delivery GM Status in LE

In LE inbound delivery, the Goods Receipt status will remain Completed (no changes).


Figure 10/B - Check Inbound Delivery Document Flow in LE

But in the document flow, a goods reversal material document (w/ movement type 102) will be created and added.

9- Check Purchase Order History in ERP (Tx. ME23N  / App. Display Purchase Order)


Figure 11 - Check PO History in ERP

NOTE: In case the missing item has been delivered by supplier later on after the goods receipt reversal for the same item was executed, a new inbound delivery should be created in this case as re-posting goods receipt for same inbound delivery item which was reversed is not possible.

 

Common Errors during Goods Receipt Reversal:

- M7328 - Deficit of Delivered quantity:
In case you enter higher quantity than original delivery item quantity.

- /SCWM/GM401 - Reversal for stock assigned to reference documents is not allowed:
In case you select a stock line with a delivery reference (i.e. DCO <> 9) or you select a stock item with open quality inspection document.

- /SCWM/GM402 - Stock Information in delivery/item - doesn't match selected stock:
In case you select a different stock line that doesn't match the inserted delivery information.

 

Out of Scope:

  • Posting goods receipt for same inbound delivery item which was revesred.
  • Serial number managed materials. (only via API is possible)
  • Catch weight managed materials.
  • Purchase documents are archived.
  • STO, Merchandise Cross docking, and TCD.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Conclusion:

It's now possible to reverse goods receipt after final putaway in EWM for external procurment scenario, using the new Monitor Method - Reversal after Putaway in Warehouse Management Report, the warehouse user is now able to trigger goods receipt reversal in EWM and ERP respectively without too much complexity or additional technical knowledge. 

You can also use the API interface /SCWM/IF_API_RVS_STOCK_PTWY in a custom development to perform the reversal.

For more information about reversal after putaway, please check Reversal of Goods Receipt from External Procurement | SAP Help Portal.

For more information about other new EWM features in S/4HANA 2025 FPS00, please check the following blog post by Gheorghe Ceres: SAP Extended Warehouse Management for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition, 2025 FPS00 ‚Äì What‚Äôs New
 
Learn more about SAP Premium Engagement and how a global team of experts can help you to get the most out of your SAP solutions.

If you already are a Premium Engagement customer, contact your Technical Quality Manager (TQM) to discuss how Premium Engagement services can help you with a custom-tailored and efficient service portfolio to make your project a success!

#CoE EMEA SCM1

entry.title: Generative AI, MCP and SAP; What are these and how to make the most of it?
entry.content:
Hi All,

Generative AI is the current buzzword in the market. Potentially, every clients, companies and adapting to it on fast pace. Recently SAP had introduced support for Model Context Protocol. With this particular blog, I'll be trying to make you all understand what MCP is, how we can make the best use of it for your SAP systems.

What is Model context protocol? (MCP)?
 It is basically an open, standardized approach that enables Large Language Models (LLMs) and AI agents to access up to date,  enterprise data - In our case, across SAP and other business systems on demand.

As Large Language Models (LLMs) like ChatGPT-4, Claude, Gemini, Llama3 etc evolve, we need standardized ways to connect them to tools, APIs, and systems. Imagine trying to follow different connectors/API for each LLM!
However, these models operate in isolation based on pre-trained data and don‚Äôt have built-in access to real-time data, databases , external APIs, or local files. Which is where MCP kicks in.

Below figure shows how MCP Client( Potentially LLMs or AI Agents) could connect to SAP systems.

MCP follows a client-server architecture, where:

  • Clients (like AI applications or LLMs) connect to
  • Servers (MCP tool providers) expose tools, APIs, or data sources to clients.

In our case, As an example- We can connect any AI agent to automate the workflows, or any AI models, using MCP to SAP systems, which would have access to the system and train from enterprise data.

Potential Use-cases:

  1. SAP GUI automation- Autonomous GUI Agent:

    Agent to automate interactions with SAP GUI, enabling programmatic control of SAP transactions. This can automate manual processes, activities which users perform on day to day basis.

    Automation scope:

    • Automation and workflows
    • Automating repetitive SAP business processes and transactions
    • Extracting specific data from SAP screens and tables for reporting or analysis
    • Integrating SAP GUI automation into AI-powered desktop assistants or custom applications

    How does it work?

    AI Agent can be fed with recorded steps, It can read and understand the fields, adapt with time; Unlike using RPA which is trained to exactly copy and execute the system actions.


    Advantage:
    Automate repetitive, heinous tasks.

  2. Enhanced Analytics and Reporting- Create dashboard and statistics.
    Scope:
    System reads, understands data and patterns and potentially (examples) answer below queries:

    ‚ÄúWhats the usage of product XXX?‚Äù
    ‚ÄúTell me the product which is most used during XXX months/quarter?‚Äù

    Advantage:
    Build dashboards, reports instantly based on the data required

  3. Understand what custom functionality does, AI can read the code, Create of functional, technical documentations:

    Let‚Äôs consider a case where a vendor has done custom development and It is a blackbox to us, AI helps us to read, analyze and provide a basic understanding of the custom enhancement, saving time and efforts. The same can be extracted as documentation for future references.

    Examples:
    ‚ÄúExplain this legacy ABAP report in plain english and add detailed in-line comments‚Äù

    Result- Understand complex, undocumented Z-programs, making analysis and decisions faster.

  4.  Fiori MCP Server/Write UI5 code using agents:

    -Developers can build apps faster using MCP servers.
    -Write UI5 code using agents.

    Examples:
    ‚ÄúAdd flexible row layout for the app‚Äù
    ‚ÄúGenerate a new project and SAP Fiori app based on ‚Äúmy sketch.jpg‚Äù

    ‚ÄúHow can I style an sap.m.Button to appear as a "reject" action?"
    "Help me migrate any deprecated UI5 API usage in this UI5 controller"

     

     

  5.  AI Assisted coding:

    MCP Clients to assist Consultants with coding, code reviews etc

  6. Smart IoT, Yard integrations, Smart Dock scheduling, Automated calls etc

    -Attain End to End track and trace information for Boxes with prompting

    -Dock Appointment scheduling using phone calls with AI voice assistant.

     

  7. Custom Chatbot- Only integrated for client data:

    End users can enquire, ask things to the chatbox which is integrated with SAP. (Can be Enabled for consultants as well).

    • Gain Information on business processes; In most organizations, Information relevant to any business process is often scattered across multiple business applications, databases, cloud systems, and files, both inside and outside of SAP. 
    • For AI agents to deliver meaningful answers and actions, they need access to all relevant data, not just data isolated SAP tables. 
    • With MCP, the connection between entire enterprise system and AI agents can be built easily.

     

  8.  How could this fit in EWM?

    Since I come from EWM (Extended Warehouse Management) background, These are few use-cases which I had in mind:
    • Custom Chatbot- only integrated for client data
    • Demand Forecasting- Enable models to predict future demand of products
    • Slotting & rearrangement- Suggest optimal bin placement for products- Helping drastically in production, Kanban processes, Urgent flows etc
    • Labour Management-Estimate, optimize workforce allocation.
    • Picking optimization- Learn, optimize picking routes for different processes on floor.
    • Learn queue, issues, patterns and take corrective/follow on actions.

     

    Please do share your feedback, ideas pertaining to your modules and your thoughts. Thanks for your time!

    Aman Orchard

entry.title: SAP‚Äôs New Logistics Management Module: A Cloud-Native Approach to Smarter Regional Supply Chains
entry.content:
At SAP Connect 2025 in Los Angeles, SAP unveiled a number of innovations in the supply chain space and one of the most notable is SAP Logistics Management, a new cloud-native solution designed to streamline and unify logistics operations  across warehouses, transportation, and logistics partners.

This launch reflects SAP‚Äôs strategy to simplify logistics for distributed and regional operations while enabling real-time visibility, automation, and collaboration across the supply chain network.

In this blog post, I will take you through what the module is, what its capabilities are, how it fits into the SAP ecosystem, and what it means for companies looking to modernise their logistics operations and all within one intelligent cloud platform.

Read the full blog to explore features, business impact, and practical steps to prepare your logistics operations for the next generation of SAP innovation.

What Is SAP Logistics Management?

SAP Logistics Management is a modern SaaS-based logistics solution built on the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).
It brings together warehousing, transportation management, and partner collaboration in a single, integrated system ‚Äî particularly suited for regional or satellite operations  while connecting seamlessly with SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Business Network.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Image Source: SAP Product Information Page (sap.com)

Key Attributes

  • Cloud-native: Designed for seamless scalability, continuous innovation, and rapid deployment.
  • Unified logistics approach: Combines warehouse, transport execution, orchestration, and partner collaboration into one platform.
  • Native ERP integration: Connects easily with SAP Cloud ERP and SAP S/4HANA without heavy customisation.
  • Carrier & partner collaboration: Built-in connectivity through the SAP Business Network for real-time visibility and data sharing.
  • AI-powered operations (Joule): Leverages SAP Joule AI assistants to automate tasks, guide decisions, and reduce manual workload.

In short, SAP Logistics Management doesn‚Äôt replace heavy-duty logistics systems like SAP EWM or SAP TM, but rather extends SAP‚Äôs portfolio with a lighter, agile, intelligent logistics layer ideal for regional warehouses and distributed networks.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Image Source: SAP Product Information Page (sap.com)

Core Capabilities & Business Impact

 

Function

Business Impact

Warehouse & transport execution

Reduces manual coordination and errors

Real-time visibility

Enables proactive decision-making

Dock & appointment scheduling

Improves yard efficiency

AI-guided automation

Speeds up repetitive tasks

Integrated partner collaboration

Boosts transparency across the supply chain

 

Feature Highlights

Feature Area

What It Enables

Why It Matters

Warehouse execution

Pick/pack, wave management, dock scheduling, inventory movements

Smooth internal operations, less idle time

Transportation & dispatching

Route planning, dispatching, and execution

Better shipment coordination

Network collaboration

Real-time status, carrier integration, partner communication

Reduces blind spots, accelerates response

Appointment & dock scheduling

Dock/gate management

Reduces queuing, improves yard efficiency

AI automation (Joule)

Decision support, task automation

Frees up planners and boosts productivity

ERP integration

Out-of-the-box connectivity with SAP Cloud ERP

Minimizes custom development

Scalable deployment

Rapid implementation for smaller logistics nodes

Supports multi-tier logistics networks

 

Positioning Within the SAP Ecosystem

SAP positions this module as a bridge for distributed logistics operations, extending logistics capabilities to smaller or regional nodes. It complements, not replaces the SAP Extended Warehouse Management and SAP Transportation Management .

Where It Fits:

SAP Product

Complexity

Ideal For

Deployment

SAP EWM

High

Central hubs

On-prem / Cloud

SAP TM

High

Complex transport networks

On-prem / Cloud

SAP Logistics Management

Medium / Low

Regional / Satellite nodes

Cloud-native

Because it‚Äôs built on SAP BTP and integrates with SAP Business Network and Joule AI, the new module aligns with SAP‚Äôs vision of an intelligent, integrated supply chain.
SAP announced that general availability is expected in Q1 2026.

Benefits & Business Value

Adopting SAP Logistics Management can deliver both operational and strategic gains:

  1. Reduced operational friction: Unified logistics reduces manual handoffs and integration gaps.
  2. Faster deployment for regional nodes: Cloud-native architecture enables quicker rollouts and lower implementation costs.
  3. Improved visibility & collaboration: Real-time tracking and partner integration enhance transparency and agility.
  4. AI-driven decision support: Joule AI assists planners, automates routine actions, and reduces human error.
  5. Scalable, modular growth: Deploy gradually across logistics nodes without disrupting existing core systems.
  6. Resilient and agile operations: Respond faster to disruptions and maintain consistent service levels.
  7. Network consistency: Standardised processes and data across multiple logistics layers ensure global alignment.

Key Challenges & Considerations

While promising, success depends on thoughtful execution.
Organisations should anticipate and plan for:

  • Scope & complexity limits: The module is optimised for low-to-medium complexity; large hubs may still need EWM + TM.
  • Data integration & master data quality: Consistent, clean master data is critical for seamless performance.
  • Change management: AI-driven workflows require user adoption and training.
  • Phased rollout strategy: Identify pilot nodes and migration paths carefully.
  • Carrier & partner readiness: True collaboration depends on network adoption.
  • Monitoring & exception handling: Maintain human oversight during early automation phases.
  • Cost vs. ROI alignment: Evaluate expected efficiency gains against investment costs.

 

What Businesses Should Do Next

If your organization already runs SAP Cloud ERP or S/4HANA, this launch presents a real opportunity to modernise logistics without starting from scratch.

Recommended Next Steps

  • Map your logistics footprint: Identify which regional or satellite nodes would benefit most.
  • Start with pilot deployments: Test configurations, training, and ROI in smaller sites.
  • Ensure data readiness: Clean up and harmonize master data across materials, locations, and partners.
  • Engage carriers early: Align carriers and logistics partners with the collaboration network from the start.
  • Plan coexistence: Integrate with existing EWM/TM during the transition phase.
  • Adopt AI in stages: Roll out automation features gradually and monitor outcomes.
  • Track KPIs from day one: Measure order throughput, dock utilisation, exception rates, and on-time delivery.

Conclusion 

The introduction of SAP Logistics Management marks a pivotal step in SAP‚Äôs supply chain evolution - moving toward networked, intelligent, and modular logistics.

With its cloud-native architecture, AI-powered automation, and embedded collaboration, it offers a compelling value proposition for companies with multi-tier logistics footprints.

Ultimately, success will depend on data readiness, partner engagement, and phased adoption but for organisations ready to embrace intelligent logistics, SAP is clearly paving the way for smarter, more connected supply chains.

Thank you for reading.

entry.title: Reimagining Logistics for the Cloud Era ‚Äî Inside SAP Logistics Management
entry.content:
Many small and mid-sized companies still depend on siloed systems: an old WMS here, spreadsheets for transportation, and emails for carrier updates. The result? Disconnected visibility, inefficiency, and rising logistics cost.

SAP Logistics Management (LGM) reimagines this landscape.
Built natively on the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), LGM unifies warehousing, transportation, and network collaboration into a single intelligent cloud platform. It brings the power of SAP EWM, SAP TM, and SAP Business Network for Logistics (BN4L) together for the first time in a cloud-native experience.

Solution Overview ‚Äî Unified, Scalable, and Built for the Cloud

SAP Logistics Management bridges execution gaps by bringing every logistics function into a unified flow: from goods receipt to shipment confirmation, across multiple warehouses, modes, and carriers.

Source: 4577_SAP_Logistics_Management_L2_Public

Key Design Principles

Principle Description
Cloud-nativeSaaS architecture, auto-updates, minimal IT footprint.
Unified logistics layerIntegrates warehouse, transport, and carrier collaboration.
AI-enabledEmbedded Joule AI assistant supports planning and exception handling.
Network-readyPre-integrated with SAP Business Network for Logistics.
Composable & scalableAdopt modules progressively (start small, scale fast).

Functional Scope ‚Äî From Warehouse to Network

SAP LGM delivers four main functional pillars:

  1. Warehouse Logistics (cloud EWM capabilities)

  2. Transportation Logistics (cloud TM capabilities)

  3. Network Collaboration (integrated with BN4L)

  4. Unified Planning & Control (real-time visibility cockpit)

Each pillar comes with its own set of Fiori apps, use cases, and business value.

Warehouse Logistics ‚Äî Cloud EWM Simplified

Warehouse Logistics in LGM handles end-to-end inbound, internal, and outbound warehouse operations. Designed for ease of adoption, it provides structured receiving, storage, and dispatch processes with mobile execution and embedded analytics ‚Äî all running in the cloud.

Category Capabilities Business Benefit

InboundGoods receipt, putaway, inspectionReduce manual errors and waiting time.
InternalBin management, replenishmentOptimize space and movement.
OutboundPicking, packing, staging, loadingFaster fulfillment accuracy.
MobileScanning & task confirmationReal-time execution; paperless workflow.
MonitoringDashboards & alertsImprove supervisory visibility.

Warehouse Monitor App: Imagine a retailer‚Äôs regional warehouse receiving 200 SKUs per day. The supervisor uses Warehouse Monitor to see that Putaway Zone B is overloaded while Zone C is idle. Within seconds, tasks are rebalanced to maintain service levels ‚Äî no need for spreadsheets.

Key Fiori Apps in Warehouse Logistics

App Name Usage
Warehouse MonitorSupervisors track workload, resources, exceptions.
Execute Warehouse TasksOperators perform putaway/picking with handhelds.
Manage Inbound DeliveriesCreate, monitor, and post receipts for inbound deliveries.

Transportation Logistics ‚Äî Intelligent Freight Orchestration

Transportation Logistics in LGM brings planning, tendering, execution, and freight costing into one intelligent workflow. It eliminates spreadsheet-based planning and manual RFQs by integrating real-time carrier collaboration.

Category Capabilities Business Benefit
PlanningLoad building, route optimisation & consolidationCut freight costs and carbon footprint.
TenderingPeer-to-peer / broadcast to carriersAutomate carrier selection.
ExecutionFreight order tracking & event managementAchieve end-to-end visibility.
CostingFreight cost calculation & invoice reconciliationImprove financial accuracy.
AppointmentDock scheduling & time windowsReduce waiting time and idle assets.

Manage Freight RFQs App: A chemical manufacturer planning an urgent dispatch to Delhi creates an RFQ in LGM. Three carriers receive tenders instantly via BN4L; within minutes, Carrier A accepts with best price and lead time ‚Äî no emails or phone calls needed.

Key Fiori Apps in Transportation Logistics

App Name Usage
Manage Freight RFQsCreate/manage carrier RFQs.
Tender Freight OrdersPublish freight offers to carriers.
Track Freight OrdersView live shipment events & status.

Network Collaboration ‚Äî Connected by Design

Network Collaboration within SAP LGM links shippers and carriers digitally via the SAP Business Network for Logistics. It replaces emails and calls with structured collaboration ‚Äî carrier tenders, dock appointments, shipment events, and POD uploads all happen in one network workspace.

Category Capabilities Business Benefit
Carrier CollaborationTender acceptance / status updatesFaster onboarding, less manual follow-up.
Appointment SchedulingDock slot managementSmoother inbound/outbound flow.
Tracking & EventsMilestones & delay alertsPredictive visibility.
DocumentationProof of Delivery / Freight invoice sharingPaperless compliance.

Manage Carrier Collaboration App: A transport partner accepts a freight order from the shipper and uploads the signed POD once delivery is complete. The system automatically updates LGM and triggers freight invoice posting in ERP.

Key Fiori Apps in Network Collaboration

App Name Usage
Manage Carrier CollaborationDigital tender acceptance & status updates.
Schedule Dock AppointmentsDock slot coordination with carriers.
Monitor Shipment MilestonesTrack shipment events and POD status.

Unified Planning & Control ‚Äî Visibility in One View

Narrative
The Unified Planning & Control cockpit serves as the command centre for logistics execution. It integrates data from warehousing, transportation, and network collaboration into one consolidated dashboard, allowing real-time monitoring and decision-making.

Feature Description
Unified Planning ConsoleAggregate view of all logistics plans & statuses.
Control TowerMonitors execution progress and exceptions.
KPI DashboardsVisualises service levels and throughput.
Exception HandlingGuided workflows to resolve delays and errors.

Logistics Dashboard App: A distribution manager opens the dashboard each morning to view all facilities on one screen. If a lane‚Äôs OTD drops below 95 %, he drills into that carrier and sends an RFQ for replacement service ‚Äî action taken within minutes, not days.

Key Fiori Apps in Unified Planning & Control

App Name Usage
Logistics DashboardKPI overview of logistics network.
Exception Management HubCentralised issue tracking & resolution.
Dashboard for PlanningCompare planned vs actual performance.

Integration ‚Äî Seamless by Default

LGM connects to SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Business Network using standard APIs and content packages. Data flows bi-directionally for deliveries, goods movements, freight costs and invoices. This ensures a single source of truth across finance and operations.

Intelligence Layer ‚Äî Joule AI for Smarter Decisions

Joule, SAP‚Äôs AI copilot, is built into LGM. It understands context, answers in natural language, and automates common decisions like carrier selection or route replanning.

Source: 4577_SAP_Logistics_Management_L2_Public

A planner types, ‚ÄúWhich deliveries are at risk today?‚Äù Joule returns a list of orders facing delays and suggests rescheduling or alternate carriers based on historic performance. The planner approves in one click ‚Äî no manual analysis

Business Benefits ‚Äî Tangible Value for Growing Companies

Area Impact
SpeedGuided cloud deployment reduces implementation time by 50 %.
VisibilityUnified planning console gives end-to-end control.
EfficiencyAI and automation reduce manual coordination effort.
ScalabilityStart with one site or process, expand as needed.
Continuous InnovationQuarterly updates add new features without upgrades.

#SAP #SAPLogisticsManagement #SAPEWM #SAPTM #SAPBusinessNetwork #SupplyChain #CloudLogistics #AIinLogistics #Joule

entry.title: Handling Unit (HU) Data in Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) - Buffer vs. Database
entry.content:
Working with Handling Units in EWM often involves understanding how the HU data is created, updated and handled by the EWM application. This post is to share my insights about the technical aspects of the HU data access.

In EWM, data that is currently being changed or created is typically kept in (transient) buffers: global tables defined in the function group /SCWM/HUMAIN as is the case with HU-buffer or object instances in the BO layer e.g. for the EWM deliveries. So, until the data is saved to the database, the ‚Äútransient‚Äù data may differ from the persistent data on the database. This needs to be considered when data is being read and it also affects the APIs (functions/methods) which are used to access the data.

In EWM, there are functions/methods that only read from the database. Others may only read from the transient buffers and others may read from both. Using a wrong method/function may result in the use of wrong (obsolete) data.

Important technical aspects for reading & updating the HU information in EWM:

  1. Make sure the changes to HU are updated and that the HU buffer is filled and up-to-date e.g. by using methods like /SCWM/IF_PACK_BAS~SAVE, /SCWM/CL_HU_PACKING->SAVE.
  2. Access the HU data from the database or from the HU buffer?
    • Read HUs from Buffer only: FM: /SCWM/HUMAIN_DATA_GET, /SCWM/HUHEADER_READ
    • Read HUs from Database only: FM: /SCWM/HU_SELECT
    • Combined Read 1. from Buffer then from DB: API: /SCWM/IF_API_HANDLING_UNIT implemented with class:  /SCWM/CL_API_HANDLING_UNIT e.g. method: READ_BY_HUIDENT which uses FM: /SCWM/HU_READ_MULT or FM: /SCWM/HU_SELECT_GEN (additionally with BAdI: /SCWM/EX_HU_SELECT)
    • Combined Read 1. From DB then from Buffer ‚Äì no standard SAP API known to me, custom wrapper might be built if needed.
  3. Update the HU buffer specifically for a single HU e.g. via FM: /SCWM/HUHDR_INT_UPDATE
  4. HU buffer Restore - if necessary, e.g. if there is incomplete data restore the HU buffer e.g. by using FM: HU_PACKING_REFRESH. This ensures that all necessary HU-related buffers are correctly populated.
  5. HU buffer Cleanup ‚Äì e.g. to be sure HUs are NOT read from buffer: via class-method: /SCWM/CL_TM=>CLEANUP, /SCWM/CL_WM_PACKING ->INIT (HU buffer refresh controlled via interface parameter), FM: /SCWM/HUMAIN_REFRESH Warning: Do not use the cleanup methods in BAdI implementations in any way, because then the buffers (global tables) of the standard processing will be reset and not available for other processes. But in the transactional processing it is important to use it. EWM transactions may behave strange if you omit to cleanup after a COMMIT WORK AND WAIT.

For all of the above mentioned methods/functions - if you are following the clean-code approach please check additionally the released APIs listed in Note: 3578329 or via the Cloudification Repository Viewer.

Example: get HU information for deleted HUs in case of the Automatic Deletion of Empty HUs (EWM customizing flag set on packaging material type: /SCWM/V_TPMTYPWM ‚Äì HUDEL). In case this flag is set and the HU gets deleted right after it gets empty then in the further processing (e.g. for warehouse task confirmation BAdI) the HU data for the deleted HU is no longer accessible via DB read, it can be read only via the HU buffer.

To summarize:
In EWM the access to the necessary HU database tables is optimized, and the results are buffered. The standard data should be accessed via (standard) APIs which often imply reading from the HU buffer first, so using the APIs to get the HU Information, the general assumption is that the Handling Unit information has already been updated in the buffer. If working with custom HU data the correct update and refresh of the buffer should also be considered.

I hope this overview is useful. Any comments / corrections / Your views on this topic are much appreciated.

entry.title: EWM BAdI Implementation Scenario-Bin Validation During Putaway (Manual Change)
entry.content:
Introduction:

In this blog, I‚Äôll explain a real-time business requirement related to bin validation during the putaway process, and how we can handle it using the BAdI /SCWM/IF_EX_CORE_PTS_VERIF~VERIFY.

Business Scenario:

In day-to-day warehouse operations, it is quite common for system-proposed storage bins (determined by the defined putaway strategy) to become temporarily unusable. This can happen for several operational reasons for instance:

  • The bin might be physically damaged or under maintenance.
  • It could be blocked physically for quality or safety reasons.
  • The bin location may be temporarily occupied or inaccessible due to congestion or space constraints.

When such situations occur, warehouse operators working on RF devices or through the desktop transaction must override the system suggestion and select an alternate destination bin manually. To handle these exceptions correctly, operators use a predefined exception code (for example, CHBD - Change Destination Bin) that allows them to modify the target bin during task confirmation.

However, under standard SAP EWM behavior, the system performs only a basic check when the user enters a new bin. It does not validate whether the manually entered bin belongs to the same storage type as the system-proposed one. This means that:

  • The operator can enter or scan any valid bin, even if it is part of a different storage type.
  • No error or warning message is triggered by default.

While this flexibility can be useful in certain dynamic warehouse setups, it also poses a significant business risk, especially in compact or high-density warehouses where bins from different storage types are physically close to each other. A small scanning or entry error could lead to incorrect stock placement, causing:

  • Inventory discrepancies between system and physical stock location.
  • Errors in subsequent picking or replenishment processes.
  • Reduced traceability of materials and increased audit effort.

Example Scenario:

The system proposes Storage Type: "Z00A", Bin: "ZONE-A-BIN-003" for putaway.

The operator, due to bin blockage, changes the destination to Storage Type: "Z00B", Bin: "ZONE-B-BIN-001.

In standard configuration, this change is accepted without any validation, even though Z00B might represent a completely different physical or logical area (for example, a cold storage zone or a bulk storage area).

Business Requirement:

To prevent such issues, the business requirement is to introduce a validation rule that ensures, 

  • Operators cannot put away stock into a bin from a different storage type than the one proposed by the system.
  • Validation should trigger only when the bin is manually changed (using exception CHBD or similar).
  • It should work both in RF screens and GUI transactions.

This is a simple but powerful requirement that helps prevent data inconsistency and operational errors.

BAdI Used:

SAP provides a BAdI specifically for this purpose:

BAdI: /SCWM/IF_EX_CORE_PTS_VERIF
Method: VERIFY

You can find this under:

SPRO ‚Üí SCM Extended Warehouse Management
‚Üí Business Add-Ins for EWM
‚Üí Goods Receipt Process
‚Üí Putaway Strategies
‚Üí BAdI: Check Destination Storage Bin

Please refer the my earlier blog to identify the BAdI in the program in more details, BAdI Implementation for Automatic Warehouse Task Selection in the Deconsolidation Work Center in EWM 

According to the SAP documentation, this BAdI is triggered only when the destination bin is manually entered.
That makes it ideal for our scenario.

Open the BAdI /SCWM/IF_EX_CORE_PTS_VERIF and go to the method VERIFY.
In this method, you can write the logic for validation. First, set a breakpoint inside the method to ensure the BAdI is being called during manual bin changes.

Refer to the screenshot below. The process starts with the inbound delivery, during which the warehouse task is created for that inbound delivery. In the RF transaction, the warehouse operator then tries to change the destination bin manually. Since we have hardcoded the breakpoint in the BAdI logic, the debugger is triggered at that point ,confirming that we have reached the correct place in the code.

When the operator manually changes the bin using an exception code (for example, CHBD) and clicks Enter, the debugger will stop at your breakpoint. This confirms that this is the right place and Badi to write the validation logic.

Within the BAdI, you will find local variables such as:

IS_LTAP

IS_T331

IS_T333

These structures/internal tables contain detailed information about the warehouse task, such as warehouse number, source bin, and destination bin. You can use these variables to write conditional logic.

For example, you can use the warehouse number (LGNUM) or other fields from IS_LTAP to apply validation filters. You can also perform a SELECT query on the open warehouse task table /SCWM/ORDIM_O to cross-check the original task data storage type and bin.

If the new bin belongs to a different storage type than the one proposed (based on the comparison logic), you can trigger an error message, prompting the operator to choose a bin within the same storage type.

You can also see the BAdI error message storage details in the screenshot below specifically, the ET_BAPIRET  internal table, which captures the error messages, and the EV_SEVERITY parameter, which stores the message type, such as error, warning, or information. Essentially, ET_BAPIRET serves as the output of this BAdI, and based on its content, the subsequent logic will execute accordingly.

Refer to the sample code  screenshot below. One key point to note is the use of filters -as shown, I‚Äôve applied multiple filters. Based on the specific business requirement, you can restrict the BAdI call to certain scenarios as needed.

Okay, so now I‚Äôve implemented the BAdI logic. When I execute the transaction again, the expected result is that the system should not allow me to proceed further - instead, it should display the corresponding error message.

Testing the Scenario:

  • Create a Warehouse Task for Putaway.
  • In RF, start the Putaway process.
  • Use the exception code CHBD to manually change the bin.
  • Enter a bin from a different storage type.
  • Observe the system validation message:- ‚ÄúNew storage bin should be within the same storage type.‚Äù

Conclusion:

Hence the implemented logic ensures:

  • Operators can change bins only within the same storage type.
    System restricts bin change across different storage types.
    Works seamlessly in both RFUI and GUI transactions.

Thank you for reading. Please share your feedback or thoughts in the comments section below-it always helps improve future content.

Disclaimer: The screenshot shown in this blog, has been captured from the S/4HANA 2023 Embedded EWM system. It is provided solely for demonstration and explanatory purposes to illustrate the configuration and logic behavior described in this document. Please note that this setup and the associated data are purely test-based and do not represent any real-time or live industry data. 

Best Regards,

Kannan Chokkanathan.

entry.title: The SAP Extended Warehouse Management FAQ Series: Robotic Integration for EWM
entry.content:
With the request to further increase the level of automation in modern and high-performance warehouses integration of robotics to warehouse management solutions becomes increasingly relevant.

This demand is leading to the question on how to best and most efficiently integrate robotics, fleet management systems and multi-agent orchestration platforms to SAP Extended Warehouse Management for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition.

With this blog post, we would like to discuss some of the most important and relevant questions of the topic of robotic integration to SAP EWM.

What is the right integration technology to integrate robotic systems to SAP EWM?

With SAP EWM there are multiple channels and interfacing options that should be evaluated when integrating robotics and the corresponding fleet management systems.

Typically, robot platforms are integrated via OData APIs, EWM-WCU IDOC interface or via SOAP Webservices and RFCs. Further AGV, AMR and robots can be integrated using MFS over TCP/IP and telegram-based communication. Find further information about available EWM interfaces and specific features and functions via the following links:

  • OData APIs for EWM: Find a list of available ODATA Services for EWM via SAP Help ‚Äì SAP S/4HANA - APIs for Warehousing or via the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.
  • EWM WCU IDoc Interface: Find a list of available IDocs for EWM via SAP Help ‚Äì SAP S/4HANA - Interface Between EWM and Non-SAP Systems.
  • SOAP Webservices for EWM: Find a list of available SOAP for EWM via SAP Help ‚Äì SAP S/4HANA - Enterprise Services in Extended Warehouse Management.

The choice of the integration technology is majorly influenced by the dedicated robotic vendor (integration to sub-systems), partner solution, requirement against end-to-end visibility, type of robotic integrated/primary function (e.g. mobile robot, manipulation robots, cognitive robots, etc.), size and heterogeny of robotic fleet.

Is there a best-practice architecture for robotic integration?

While the robotics integration is highly depending on the aspects mentioned before in the warehouse context the following types of robots are typically used (listed based on primary function):

  • Mobile Robots: Robots moving through the warehouse such as AMR (Autonomous Mobile Robots), AGV (Automated Guided Vehicles)
  • Manipulation Robots: Robots that physical handle and move items such as picking robots, sorting robots and palletizing/depalletizing robots.

In case there are larger and heterogenous robotic fleets integrated to warehouse solutions there are often Fleet Management Systems (FMS) or Multiagent Orchestration Platforms (MOP) from SAP Partners required to orchestrate and dispatch Workload (Warehouse Orders/Tasks) amongst the integrated fleet, performing position management, analytics, routing and training of robots.

Additionally, there are partner solutions on the market that are specialized on industries and process variants such as eCommerce small parts picking, which can be integrated according to a Black Box-integration pattern (EWM viewpoint), as Warehouse Orders/Tasks are optimized and dispatched via the Fleet Management System (FMS) to an integrated robotic solution (e.g. assisted picking robots).

Considering above mentioned aspects, the following integration patterns are most common and best suiting to the requirements of robotic integration:

                Event-Driven Integration

The event-driven integration considers direct distribution of relevant workload via the Warehouse Order Business Event (available with SAP S/4HANA 2025, FPS0) to the SAP Event Mesh on SAP BTP. From the SAP Event Mesh the Fleet Manager System (FMS) can pick-up the relevant Warehouse Order creation, cancelation, activation or deletion events to initiate retrieving relevant Warehouse Orders.

The integration follows the following steps:

  1. Create warehouse task/- order for movement from source to destination
  • Source and Destination are FMS managed
  • Determine FMS relevant queue for execution
  1. Push Warehouse Order Business Event to SAP Event Mesh
  2. FMS to register for the relevant Warehouse Order Business Event from SAP Event Mesh
  3. Perform Warehouse Order/Warehouse Tasks retrieval from FMS for relevant Warehouse Orders via the Warehousing API (GET)
  4. Start execution of the Warehouse Order/Warehouse Tasks by updating the operating resource to the Warehouse Order (e.g. FMS or specific robot-unit) by the Warehousing API (POST) (optional)
  5. Confirm Warehouse Order/Warehouse Tasks by FMS by the Warehousing API (POST)

Direct Integration

In basic concept of the direct integration is to either send created Warehouse Orders/Warehouse Tasks to a Fleet Management System (FMS) or retrieve Warehouse Orders/Tasks by the Fleet Management System (FMS).

The integration follows the following steps:

  1. Create warehouse task/- order for movement from source to destination
  • Source and Destination are FMS managed
  • Determine FMS relevant queue for execution
  1. FMS to select open Warehouse Orders/Warehouse Tasks regularly from queue via EWM interface (e.g. ODATA-service, WebService, IDoc).
  2. Start execution of the Warehouse Order/Warehouse Tasks by setting updating the operating resource to the Warehouse Order (e.g. FMS or specific robot-unit)
  3. Confirm Warehouse Order/Warehouse Tasks by FMS

Additionally, there are project-based integrations possible, to integrate robotics via MFS-telegrams or with small robotic fleets to directly integrate robots to EWM.

What is the typical SAP EWM configuration required for robotic integration?

To enable transparency and optimized integration the following customizing is typically configured in SAP EWM:

  • Queues and Queue determination criteria for robots
  • Resource Types for robots
  • Resource Groups for robots
  • Queue sequence for robot‚Äôs Resource Group
  • Resource for robot

Implementation of the following interface functions to connect robots with SAP EWM:

  • Push Warehouse Order Events (create, change, delete, activate) to FMS
  • Retrieve Warehouse Orders
  • Assign Robot to Warehouse Order
  • Confirm Warehouse Orders

We are currently evaluating further enhancements to standard functionality on SAP EWM roadmap to improve integration to robotic fleets to enable for a more robust and dynamic integration.

Are there partner solutions available to integutions to SAP EWM most efficiently?

We have partner solutions offering proven integration concepts and contents available via our SAP Store with the following partners:

Partner

Solution

Locus Robotics, Inc.

Locus Autonomous Mobile Robots for SAP EWM

Geekplus Technology Co., Ltd.

Improve efficiency of your warehouse operation by 2 to 3 times

DXC Technology Services LLC

DXC Smart Warehouse EWM Integration with AGVs

Flexus AG

AGV-Hub - Fleet Manager for Mobile Robots

KINEXON Industries GmbH

Connect and automate operations: redefine manufacturing & logistics efficiency

Roboteon Inc.

Roboteon Fulfillment Platform

Beside these there are implementation accelerators and partner solutions available from our partner ecosystem that are not listed yet in the SAP Store.

What is the future of robotic integration with SAP EWM?

With advancing technology both in logistics, business solutions and robotics, new ways of integration are explored and driven forward. SAP‚Äôs initiative to combine advanced robotics with enhanced sensorics and AI capabilities ‚Äì cognitive robots ‚Äì and AI-infused logistics solutions leads the way towards new opportunities for automation.

BITZER, NEURA Robotics and SAP went live with a proof-of-concept solution to integrate embodied AI agents to EWM for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition. The proof-of-concept validates Joule-based multi-agent orchestration and execution via the humanoid robot 4NE1 for a picking workflow including visual inspection, enabling agentic situation handling according to the business process and priorities. If you would like to learn more about via SAP News - SAP Expands Physical AI Partnerships and Demonstrates Success of New Robotics Pilots. 

If you would like to learn more about robotic integration, please find more information via SAP Community Blog Enhancing warehouse operations by integrating robotics with SAP Extended Warehouse Management or stay tuned for further release updates and posts.

entry.title: Automate Digital and Physical Together - Intralogistics Fleet Orchestration integrated with SAP EWM
entry.content:
Welcome, my name is Fabio Marti and I am the Vice President of Marketing at KINEXON. With this blog, I am adding to the series Enhancing warehouse operations by integrating robotics with SAP Extended Warehouse Management that has been started by @ganesh_wadawadigi  and explain how KINEXON‚Äôs solution for mobile robot fleet management can be combined with SAP EWM to give intralogistics professionals and operations leaders new levels of control and efficiency.  

Managing a warehouse or production site often means dealing with a mix of mobile robots and manually operated forklifts‚Äîeach running on different systems. This creates fragmented workflows, manual task assignments, and patchwork of disconnected software. SAP S/4HANA Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) streamlines the operations, but managing and integrating a heterogenous fleet of robots and forklifts can be challenging. KINEXON Fleet Manager eliminates the need for custom middleware or manual coordination for the diverse robot fleet to pull tasks directly from SAP EWM and execute them autonomously and report back in real time. In addition, it also allows to send jobs automatically to manual forklifts to ensure that they are well coordinate with the movement of the robots thereby optimize the execution of the jobs and reduce incidents and increase overall shopfloor efficiency. ‚ÄÉ

Connecting the Digital and Physical Worlds 

Integration of KINEXON with SAP EWM addresses the need for a scalable and out-of-the-box integration to address operational challenges such as:  

  • Lack of real-time feedback on task execution, accidents, or other outliers 
  • Risk of collisions and congestions due to forklifts being a digitally invisible free radical in your autonomous transport paths 
  • Need for custom-built middleware for every single vehicle type that is expensive and hard to maintain   
  • Limited scalability when adding new robot types or workflows 
  • Gaps in end-to-end automation, causing inefficiencies and delays 
  • Blind spots, lacking real-time visibility of moving assets 

KINEXON acts as a central orchestration layer between SAP EWM and the intralogistics fleet by bringing together all transport resources - autonomous mobile robots (AMRs), automated guided vehicles (AGVs), forklifts, tugger trains, and even manual carts ‚Äî into one intelligent control system. It uses: 

  • SAP EWM APIs to pull and report tasks that have been optimized for orchestrating warehouse activities based on several factors such as inventory levels, space and resource utilization, travel path, order priority etc. 
  • VDA 5050, a standardized communication interface for AMRs, AGVs and forklifts from different vendors 
  • Out-of-the-box integration for rapid deployment 
  • Real-time logic to assign tasks dynamically and handle exceptions 
  • Real-time tracking of manual vehicles to seamlessly integrate them into the intralogistics flow, enabling end-to-end automation 

This makes the robots become true executors of warehouse orders and tasks that are optimized by SAP EWM, requiring no manual intervention while working smoothly alongside manual transport vehicles, whose paths and locations are also fully digitized. 

KINEXON Fleet Manager functions as an Intralogistics Execution System providing standardized interfaces and integration capabilities for over 20 mobile robot vendors, such as ABB, Jungheinrich, AUMOVIO Robotic Solutions, Bosch Rexroth, MiR, Safelog, STILL, and Linde. Each robot vendor is technically certified through standardized interface validation and end-to-end process testing, ensuring full interoperability with SAP EWM; this allows SAP EWM customers to confidently select a robot vendor based on their specific operational and process requirements rather than on integration feasibility.

Integrating SAP EWM with Robot Fleet using KINEXON 

Here is a typical set up of the integration between KINEXON Fleet Manager and SAP EWM: 

  1. Creating Smart Queues in SAP
    KINEXON creates two queues:
    • One for standard warehouse tasks
    • One for tasks that fail or need manual review

KINEXON Fleet Manager keeps an eye on these queues in real time, pulling in tasks as they come.

  1. Defining the Fleet as a Resource
    Next, the Fleet Manager will be introduced to SAP EWM as if it were a worker‚Äîliterally. A virtual resource (like ‚ÄúKINEXON_FLEET‚Äù) is created so SAP EWM can assign tasks to it just like it would to a forklift or warehouse employee.
  2. Activating the Right APIs
    To make the magic happen, KINEXON activates key SAP EWM APIs: 
    • Warehouse Resource API: for resource creation and status updates
    • Warehouse Order and Task API: for pulling and updating warehouse orders

These APIs can be found on SAP Business Accelerator Hub by searching for ‚Äúwarehouse‚Äù.

  1. Configuring the Fleet Manager
    Now it is time to sync everything up. In the KINEXON Fleet Manager, customers can configure: 
    • API endpoints and credentials
    • Warehouse number and resource name
    • Polling intervals for task retrieval

This ensures the system is tightly synced with SAP EWM.

  1. Mapping Pickup and Dropoff Points
    Finally, robot navigation points will be aligned with SAP storage bins using simple naming conventions like: 
    • BIN_01-pickup for pickup points
    • BIN_02-drop for drop-off points

This makes sure every robot knows exactly where to go and what to do.

Business Benefits 

Typical benefits of KINEXON Fleet Manager integrated with SAP EWM are: 

  • Less implementation and maintenance effort 
  • Fast return on investments
  • Reduction in stoppage due to better orchestration
  • Higher fleet throughput 

A leading global tier-1 automotive supplier recently piloted the KINEXON Fleet Manager system integrated with SAP EWM to streamline intralogistics with the goal of cutting operational costs and building future-proof automation. 

The company was facing the following hurdles: 

  • Manual forklift operations slowed material transport 
  • No SAP EWM integration limited automation and real-time task execution 
  • Lack of fleet transparency made AMR tracking difficult 
  • Manual trolley handling disrupted AMR flow 
  • Gate control systems were incompatible with AMRs 

The pilot automated supply for a production line with five machines using three AMRs. Fleet Manager received orders directly from SAP EWM, coordinating AMRs for material flows while ensuring real-time tracking, optimized utilization, and on-time delivery to prevent downtime. 

Using SAP EWM‚Äôs Warehouse Order and Task ODATA API, KINEXON Fleet Manager automatically synced tasks and reported live progress, providing end-to-end visibility and seamless automation. AMRs handled raw material supply, empty material collection, finished product transport, and returns to the warehouse or packaging areas, navigating configurable Points of Interest (POIs) across production and warehouse zones. 

In summary, the benefits realized were: 

  • Order management & prioritization: Dynamic task allocation based on production needs 
  • SAP integration: Real-time task sync and monitoring via SAP dashboards 
  • VDA 5050 compatibility: Vendor-agnostic AMR support for flexibility and scalability 
  • Plug-and-play AMR onboarding: Minimal setup for new robots

entry.title: Cross delivery handling unit in Advanced shipping and receiving (ASR) in SAP S/4HANA 2025 release
entry.content:
Cross delivery handling unit means a packing box (like carton) containing products from multiple deliveries as shown in below image. Carton P contains product A and B from two deliveries X and Y respectively. Cross delivery handling unit is very effective for small parts, optimization of packing etc. 

 

Cross delivery handling unit is supported in SAP Extended warehouse management (EWM). Capability for cross handling unit for Transportation management ( TM ) and Extended warehouse management (EWM) with Transportation unit (TU) is supported from SAP S/4HANA 2021 release . Refer my blog https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-members/cross-delivery-handling-unit-in-tm-ewm-integration-in-s-4hana-2021-release/ba-p/13514920.

Advanced shipping & receiving (ASR) is a new solution for integration between Transportation management ( TM ) and Extended warehouse management (EWM) in SAP S/4HANA. ASR eliminates the requirement of Transportation unit (TU) in EWM and LDAP (Lightweight Directory Access Protocol) or web service communication between TM & EWM. This new ASR solution was introduced in FPS1 of SAP S/4HANA 2020 release and is evolving with S/4HANA releases. Refer my SAP Press book https://www.sap-press.com/introducing-advanced-shipping-and-receiving-asr-in-sap-s4hana_5836/ and blog https://www.linkedin.com/posts/mrinalkroy_ewm-tm-s4hana-activity-6996835047068610560-e3V7?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_desktop&rcm=ACoAAACqeFcBFLp4MZaIFhaLzuKFWx73dXzaU2U for more details on ASR.

Cross delivery handling unit is not supported in ASR too from S/4HANA 2025 release. My present blog is to describe the functionality of cross delivery handling unit in ASR .

Two outbound deliveries (80004555 and 80004556) relevant for ASR have been depicted in below image.

 

These deliveries are blocked for warehouse execution as in below image as they are transportation driven (i.e will be blocked till the relevant freight order is set for ‚ÄòReady for warehouse execution‚Äô.  

Freight order 6600000909 is now created with freight units created from those deliveries and then set of ‚ÄòReady for warehouse execution‚Äô . Subsequently EWM outbound deliveries also got released for warehouse execution as depicted in below image.

A handling unit 812345678000001816     is created packing both the items (products) from those deliveries as displayed in below image .

This handling unit then gets displayed as ‚ÄòCross -D HU‚Äô as highlighted in below image for both deliveries.

Both of the EWM outbound deliveries then need to be ‚ÄòSet to ready for shipping‚Äô. 

As these deliveries have a single handling unit , both of the deliveries need to be selected for ‚ÄòSet to ready for shipping‚Äô . otherwise error as in below image appears if a single delivery is chosen.

Handling unit then appears in freight order as in below image.

Handling unit is subsequently loaded to the truck and ‚ÄòPost‚Äô or Goods issue is executed.

One of the pre-requisites for cross handling unit is that the consolidation group needs to be same , otherwise below error appears.

This blog is based on my personal tests , observations , insights in S/4HANA 2025 release. Will appreciate your feedback / comments.
