entry.title: The 2025 SAP Logistics Private Cloud Advent Calendar
entry.content:
We have reached the closing month of 2025, and that means that the winter holiday season is upon us. So, in order to lighten the mood and lift up some spirits, we at the SAP Logistics private cloud Product Management team want to continue the timeless tradition of the virtual Advent calendar blog post.  

For those not familiar with the calendar, it is a Christmas tradition originating in Germany, which counts down the days until Christmas beginning with December 1st. Normally, these calendars contain sweets or other small gifts and trinkets, which are hidden behind the calendar doors representing a day. As this is a virtual calendar, we will be sharing daily various highlight content that either flew under the radar during initial publishing or we did not manage to share during the year.

We will be updating this article with a new paragraph each day up until December 24th, so you can bookmark this page until then for easier access to the daily updates.
We hope you enjoy this article and that the information you will discover proves useful and exciting.

DAY 1: SAP S/4HANA Cloud for Extended Warehouse Management Private Edition 2023 FPS03 ‚Äì What‚Äôs New

And to start off, let‚Äôs revisit our first article of the year, which covers the updates delivered with the SAP S/4HANA 2023 Feature Pack 3 release. This release further sharpened our Advanced Shipping & Receiving integration and built on the capabilities that were added in the SAP S/4HANA 2023 Feature Pack 2. We‚Äôve also introduced a new machine‚Äëlearning feature called Predictive Labor Demand Planning that helps warehouse shift managers plan daily tasks more accurately and efficiently by using historical workload records to calculate a planned duration for warehouse workload records and then use those records to plan outbound delivery orders. 

Aside from this, other highlights we delivered with this release include:

  • Introducing a new integration of decentralized Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) and Transportation Management (TM) with SAP Global Trade Services (GTS) which supports the execution of the outbound (or export) process.
  • Enabling users to search for waves, wave items, and wave-relevant warehouse requests that are part of Advanced Shipping and Receiving deliveries in the Maintain Waves app (transaction /SCWM/WAVE) and the warehouse monitor (transaction /SCWM/MON).
  • Providing users the ability to enter a text of up to 50 characters for goods issues and cancellations in several apps, for example, to add an explanation or other information to the goods movement.

To see more details on the above mentioned topics as well as see what other enhancements we delivered with this release, I highly encourage you to explore our latest ‚ÄúSAP EWM in SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS03 ‚Äì What‚Äôs New‚Äù slide deck.

You can also find more technical details and documentation on the above listed topic and others we left out via the ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs New‚Äù viewer on the Help Documentation portal.

DAY 2: SAP S/4HANA Cloud for Transportation Management Private Edition 2023 FPS03 ‚Äì What‚Äôs New 

Also at the beginning of the year, and in parallel to EWM, SAP Transportation Management saw the release of many exciting new features and updates to existing ones, such as:

  • AI-assisted Goods Receipt Analysis was enhanced by extending support for Shipment Documents with multiple deliveries and nested hierarchy structures. With this option, users can scan the shipping documents that accompany truck deliveries, analyze the documents, compare them to data already in the system, and create consignment orders with that data. This also detects multiple deliveries as well as deep packaging hierarchies.
  • We introduced a new carrier determination profile where simple criteria such as source and destination locations can be used to select the carrier. This innovation greatly simplifies the carrier determination process by allowing a simple set of rules to be defined to find the right carrier. This profile can be integrated with Excel for easier maintenance and a simulation report is also available.
  • With this release, we also improved the manual load planning capabilities. Specifically for 3D load planning, a new toolbar configuration was introduced that allows planners to define which manual load planning actions should be displayed. Manual planning is also further supported with additional usability features such as better item selection (e.g. select all of the same stack, ...) and better item positioning (e.g. align, swap, mirror, lift up&down, ...). This helps the planner to use 3D load planning more efficiently.

  • As with the integration of nJIT for inbound deliveries in SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS02, the FPS03 release offered the integration of nJIT for outbound deliveries. As in the inbound case, the logistically relevant product is the component group material. This means that the freight unit in TM is created at the component group level. The Advanced Shipping Notification can be sent with additional information such as slot number and JIT call reference.

 To see more details on the above mentioned topics as well as see what other enhancements that were delivered for SAP RM with this release, I highly encourage you to read the detailed blog article from Eric Osterroth ‚ÄúWhat's new in FP03 of Transportation Management in S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition 2023‚Äù.

DAY 3: Extended Warehouse Management in SAP S/4HANA FAQ series: update on the new Clean Core level concept

This year SAP evolved its extensibility guidelines with the clean core level concept, a new model designed to simplify qualification criteria and provide a more pragmatic approach to managing custom code in SAP Cloud ERP Private as a part of the journey to SAP Business Suite. This new maturity model categorizes extensions into four distinct levels (A, B, C, and D) based on their architectural integrity, upgrade safety, and alignment with clean core principles, allowing for a more granular assessment of an extension‚Äôs quality and upgrade stability.

Summarily, the 4 levels are the following:

Level A - Extend with SAP Build

  • Side-by-side extension based on SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP), and only use ABAP extensions with ABAP Cloud, CAP, or low/no-code tools such as SAP Build.
  • On-stack extensions with ABAP Cloud (SAP Build) based on released remote/local APIs and released extension points.

Level B - Leverage classic APIs

  • On-stack extension with classic ABAP using classic SAP extension points or classic APIs. Example: BAPIs, Classic BADIs, or ABAP list viewer implementations with Dynpro or Web Dynpro, custom objects that do not reference restricted or unsupported SAP Objects.

Level C - Access internal objects

  • Usage of SAP internal objects that are not classified or intended for customer use but documented clearly with change logs.
  • Customer extensions when the used objects are not in the category of level A or B, with changelogs. Example: internal function modules, classes, or read access to SAP tables that are not for external consumption.

Level D - Not recommended extensions

  • Usage of not recommended SAP objects or extension points or technologies.
  • Modification, certain object usage patterns (e.g. direct data write to SAP core tables), and discourage development techniques like implicit enhancements.

 For more information on what the new Clean Core methodology means for SAP EWM, please read the article for Corrine Lu, Extended Warehouse Management in SAP S/4HANA FAQ series: update on the new Clean Core level concept. For a more comprehensive and detailed overview of the new Clean Core levels, and what they mean for extensibility as a whole, please read SAP official white paper on the topic ‚ÄúClean core extensibility‚Äù.

DAY 4: The SAP Extended Warehouse Management FAQ Series: SCM Optimizer for EWM

The SCM Optimizer is a C/C++ application that can run on your application server or as a separate service on Windows or Linux. Also called the ‚ÄúOptimizer,‚Äù it‚Äôs used by SAP backend systems‚Äîlike Transportation Management and Extended Warehouse Management‚Äîto solve problems using algorithm-driven approaches.

The Optimizer includes multiple specialized engines, each delivered as a separate executable in the package. These engines target different optimization tasks‚Äîscheduling, network planning, package building, and so on‚Äîso you can pick the one that fits your scenario.

Since SAP EWM 9.5, the SCM Optimizer (VSO engine) can be used in EWM through the integration of Package Building (PB) for packing in inbound processes, repacking, outbound delivery processes, as well as posting changes and stock transfer. 

The primary advantage of PBO is its ability to build optimized pallets and packages for products of different sizes by taking both dimensions and weight into account. It does not require predefined package instructions or specifications; instead, it uses a 3D packing algorithm‚Äîsimilar to ‚Äú3D Tetris‚Äù‚Äîto arrange items efficiently. Basic stacking rules are provided, with options for more detailed configuration when needed. Results can be visualized in a 3D scene via transaction /SCMB/TEST_UBP.

 

To read more about how to use and install the optimizer, or on which systems you can use it, please read the blog post on the topic ‚ÄúThe SAP Extended Warehouse Management FAQ Series: SCM Optimizer for EWM‚Äù.

Learn more about Unified Package Building in EWM and Unified Package Building via SAP Help.

As we gradually introduced new features, you can find an good overview on which process is supported by UPB via SAP Note information 3076865 - Unified Package Building: Additional Application-Specific Information.

DAY 5: Reporting of GHG emissions with SAP Transportation Management

Transportation Management ‚Ñ¢ in SAP S/4HANA 2023 brought expanded capabilities to calculate, include in planning, and visualize the carbon footprint of transportation‚Äîmaking it easier to see and act on the emissions impact of your logistics.

The Sustainability area within TM gives a clear, consolidated overview of these features. For the required master data setup to get accurate calculations, check out the blog post ‚ÄúMaintain Carbon Emission on Vehicle Type‚Äù by Michael Haase.

Additionally, we provided the option to manually maintain received actual emission values for your Transportation Orders, as provided by the carrier. What has been lacking, until this release, is the capability to automatically update these actual values using an API.

In the first blog post on the topic by my colleague Holger Wittmer, titled ‚ÄúReporting of GHG emissions - Receiving actual emissions sent by your carrier‚Äù the aim was to equip you with the tools necessary to achieve automated actual emission value updates on the header level, contributing to your sustainability journey.

KBA 3654588 outlines the step-by-step process for accomplishing this.

In the second blog post by Holger, titled ‚ÄúReporting of GHG emissions - Receiving actual emissions sent by your BN4L system‚Äù, he highlighted an exciting new business feature for customers operating a Business Network for Logistics system (BN4L) using GTT 2511. This feature enables users to receive GHG emissions data sent by the BN4L system, where they not only have the capability to receive actual emission data in the BN4L system from the carrier but also to forward this data to the Transportation Management system.

For more details and sources on these new Sustainability features available with SAP Transportation Management, please visit the blogs by Holger Wittmer linked above.

DAY 6: The SAP Logistics Management What‚Äôs New release articles

A very exciting surprise this year was the release of SAP Logistics Management, a new SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) based state-of-the-art and best-of-breed native cloud logistics solution in Supply Chain Management that combines warehousing‚ÄØand transportation management‚ÄØto streamline your operations‚ÄØwith network-centric collaboration.

SAP Logistics Management complements our best-in-class logistics portfolio with a new logistics solution to manage smaller local and satellite operations. It can cater to a variety of customers and scenarios, such as:

  • Large enterprises with smaller market unit operations that want to connect to an enterprise wide ERP backend
  • Smaller wholesale distribution operations such as local distribution facilities serving a dedicated region
  • Fast growing companies with e-commerce fulfilment needs wanting to start small and scale the solution as business grows
  • Companies wanting to set up warehousing facilities flexibly such as for ramp-up/ tear down warehousing, or overflow warehouses
  • Outsourced Logistics 3PL running manufacturing or distribution warehouses, where the shipper requires full stock transparency and process execution status
  • Businesses with small single site operations such as for spare parts, low volume products or special materials or products or smaller stock room operations

In SAP Logistics Management, new features are released on a bi-weekly basis, so here I want to share the first three What‚Äôs New blog posts written by SAP Logistics Product manager Nadine Ried:

  • In this first What‚Äôs New blog post, you can read about how to change destination bin on Warehouse Task confirmation, how to create warehouse tasks in inbound and outbound via a dialog, which actions you can perform using the ‚ÄúView 3D Warehouse Layout‚Äù app, what features are available with the integration of Joule into SAP Logistics Management, and much more.
  • In the second What‚Äôs New blog post, you can find out how you can view and analyze logs related to the process of posting goods receipts to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and which insights are available, which enhancements are available for landing page on SAP Build WorkZone, how the Packing Work Centre was enhanced to reduce manual data entry when working with shipping handling units, and more.
  • In the third available What‚Äôs New blog post, you can read about the Usability improvements for consignments and transportation requests, how to create ad hoc warehouse tasks for stock with a reference to an outbound warehouse request, find out about a new app where you can upload a spreadsheet file containing stock data to be posted into the system, how to import sites in your organizational models via the Import Organizational Model app, and much more

DAY 7: The SAP Extended Warehouse Management FAQ Series: Release Strategy for Warehouse Management

SAP has a long-standing commitment to helping customers run warehouse operations with flexibility and efficiency ‚Äî from simple setups to the most complex, industry-specific scenarios. With solutions like LE-WM, Stock Room Management, SAP Extended Warehouse Management (EWM), EWM for SAP S/4HANA, and SAP Warehouse Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, we keep evolving our portfolio to provide the right fit for every market segment.

We continuously enhance EWM for SAP S/4HANA with a clear focus on three main themes:

  • Embedded AI: boosting warehouse efficiency, enabling data-driven decisions, and simplifying the user experience.
  • Suite integration and modularization: creating deep links between warehousing, manufacturing and production, transportation management, order management, and logistics network solutions.
  • Industry-driven feature expansion: extending capabilities and functions to meet specific sector needs.

EWM is an integral part of SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud and on-premise, and since SAP S/4HANA 2023 we deliver a major release every two years. Between those major releases we ship three feature packs that bring additional innovations and features aligned with our strategic north star.

With the blog post authored by Gunther Sanchez, we offered an insight on the most relevant questions when it comes to release strategy, important milestones and transformation project planning for SAP‚Äôs warehouse management solutions, as well as links to other great informational sources such as:

  • Check the specific maintenance plan for SAP EWM releases via the SAP Product Availability Matrix
  • Learn more about the SAP S/4HANA release and maintenance strategy via SAP News Center - New SAP S/4HANA Release and Maintenance Strategy to Deliver Greater Innovation and Flexibility and SAP Maintenance Phases
  • Review the SAP Road Map Explorer to learn more about the specific Future Features and innovations we are planning with upcoming SAP S/4HANA Supply Chain for Extended Warehouse Management releases

DAY 8: SAP S/4HANA Logistics Private Cloud Edition FAQ - Solution deployment scenarios EWM-TM Integration

With SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud there are two options available to integrate solution components Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) and Transportation Management (TM) available:

  • Transportation Unit-based integration
  • Advanced Shipping and Receiving (Adv. SR)

 The decision when to choose which integration depends on multiple factors:

  • Technical Architecture: Performance and scalability, Data Center Strategy, deployment and instance strategy
  • Transformation strategy: Logistics transformation before, during or after SAP S/4HANA transformation, roll-out planning
  • Requirements on maintenance and operations: Independent innovation and upgrade cycles for warehouse and transportation management functions
  • Functional solution capabilities and integration design: Centralized or distributed transportation management capabilities (e.g. procurement, planning, settlement), communication within business network, transportation planning vs. load consolidation, integration of multiple different warehouse management solutions, etc.).

With the blog post ‚ÄúSolution deployment scenarios EWM-TM Integration‚Äù we offer some guidance to help you choose the right EWM - TM integration scenario depending on the specific requirements and considering the constrains given for your transformation project. The major aspects are the evaluation of deployment scenario, business capabilities and solution capabilities. As analysis of these aspects can lead to conflicting results it is recommended to discuss these with various stakeholders within your organization to find the solution best fitting to your business transformation strategy.

DAY 9: SAP EWM Podcast: Is It Art or Can It Be Thrown Away? Archiving in SAP EWM!

It wouldn‚Äôt be a classical SAP Logistics private cloud advent calendar without highlighting some of the great advisory content provided by Andreas Rupp. In today‚Äôs highlight I want to point out his article on the topic of archiving in SAP EWM.

In warehouse management, efficiency and performance matter more than ever ‚Äî yet one task that often gets overlooked is archiving in SAP Extended Warehouse Management (EWM). Organizing and cleaning up might not be anyone‚Äôs favorite job, whether at home or in IT, but it‚Äôs crucial for keeping your system clean, fast, and ready for the future.

Archiving isn‚Äôt just about freeing up space‚Äîit‚Äôs a strategic necessity. Here are the key reasons to regularly clean up your SAP system:

  • Performance Optimization: Smaller database tables mean faster queries, shorter load times, and improved response times in daily operations.
  • Cost Efficiency: SAP HANA uses RAM-based storage, which is significantly more expensive than traditional disk storage. Reducing data volume can lower costs, especially during migrations to S/4HANA.
  • Clean Core Alignment: A lean system is easier to maintain and upgrade. Archiving supports the Clean Core principle by minimizing unnecessary data and avoiding workarounds that complicate system architecture.

The blog post ‚ÄúIs It Art or Can It Be Thrown Away? Archiving in SAP EWM!‚Äú explores the importance of archiving in SAP EWM, what data should be archived or deleted, how it ties into broader concepts like Clean Core and compliance, which guidance and tools are available for clean up, and much more.

DAY 10: The SAP Extended Warehouse Management FAQ Series: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Integration

Many customers using standardized Finance, Controlling, and Order Management processes in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud are looking for ways to add advanced warehouse management to support logistics needs and fuel growth. With SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508, a new scope item was added to let customers integrate S/4HANA Public Cloud with EWM for SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud‚Äîso that they can keep their standardized cloud ERP processes while integrating in powerful, advanced warehouse capabilities.

We support the integration of a single SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud tenant (with or without Cloud WM) to a single EWM for SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud instance. Additionally, a further SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud instance can be integrated to the same EWM for SAP S/4HANA. Please note that the SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud instance can only be used as a decentral EWM logistics system as the integration of multiple SAP S/4HANA or SAP ECC systems to EWM on SAP S/4HANA embedded not supported (see also SAP Note 3376453 - SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS00, FPS01, FPS02 and FPS03: Release information and restrictions for E...).

With the blog post ‚ÄúThe SAP Extended Warehouse Management FAQ Series: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Integration‚Äù we answer many of the questions surrounding the integration of SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and EWM for SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud, and provide useful information such as which releases are required for set-up, which functional scope is supported with this integration, what are the restrictions to be considered during implementation, and more. We wish you a pleasant and informative read, and stay tuned to this advent blog post for more regarding the topics of integration and migration.

DAY 11: The SAP Extended Warehouse Management FAQ Series: Migration to S/4HANA EWM on Private Cloud

And since we mentioned Private Cloud in the entry above, I would be remiss if I did not also put the spotlight on an article written by Corrine Lu dealing with frequently asked question regarding EWM migration to SAP S/4HANA on private cloud.

To migrate EWM master data and customizing, we have provided 34 migration objects via the SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit. The SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit allows migration per warehouse number using pre-configured migration objects. You can find an overview of the available EWM migration objects via the SAP Help page Migration Objects for SAP S/4HANA.

The migration tool provides the options for direct data transfer, the usage of staging tables, as well as file-upload. To migrate from SAP EWM (e.g. 9.5) to EWM on SAP S/4HANA the 29-migration object for direct data transfer can be used. 

For migration from LE-WM to EWM on SAP S/4HANA we provided 5 migration objects that enable migration via staging tables, available since SAP S/4HANA 2023, FPS1:

  • Warehouse Fixed Bin Assignment
  • Warehouse Stock
  • Warehouse Storage Bin
  • Warehouse Storage Bin Sorting

Both direct data transfer and staging table approaches enable the migration process with high amount of data (such as warehouse stock) for optimized error handling throughout the migration process.

In the blog post ‚ÄúThe SAP Extended Warehouse Management FAQ Series: Migration to S/4HANA EWM on Private Cloud‚Äù we provide answers to many migration questions, such as what tools are available for S/4HANA EWM migration, what migration paths to S/4 are available for LE-WM customers, what should be taken into consideration when choosing a deployment option (embedded vs. decentral) for EWM on SAP S/4HANA, what to do if you also have some industrial add-ons on your SAP EWM 9.x, and much more.

DAY 12: Streamlining Manufacturing Logistics with clean core API‚Äôs

Today I would like to highlight a very recent blog post from one of the newest members of the SAP Logistics private cloud product management team, Jan Moells, with his debut article focusing on APIs that help streamline manufacturing logistics and keep them in line with the new Clean Core strategy.

In the rapidly moving world of manufacturing logistics, agility and minimizing complexity is crucial. SAP S/4HANA for Manufacturing Logistics, with its latest API updates, is supporting this pace by separating extensions and integrations from core processes, reducing total cost of ownership (TCO), improving agility and enabling integration with analytics and cloud services. These updates can genuinely transform how you run your manufacturing logistics operations, and here is a brief overview of these updates:

  • Route Train Operations (A2X) - integrate external applications to optimize loading and unloading processes in warehouses and production environments
  • Shuttle Operator (A2X) - integrate external applications to optimize loading and unloading processes for shuttles in manufacturing and warehouse environments
  • Shuttle Configuration (A2X) - enhance shuttle loading and unloading workflows by providing essential transport and carrier data

 

 Please check out Jan‚Äôs blog post ‚ÄúStreamlining Manufacturing Logistics with clean core API‚Äôs‚Äù to find out more details on these APIs, how they can benefit your manufacturing logistics operations, examples on what‚Äôs possible with Manufacturing Logistics APIs, and more.

DAY 13: The SAP Extended Warehouse Management FAQ Series: Robotic Integration for EWM

As warehouses push for higher levels of automation, integrating robotics into warehouse management is becoming increasingly essential. That raises the question of how to most efficiently connect robotics, fleet-management systems and multi-agent orchestration platforms with SAP Extended Warehouse Management for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition.

With SAP EWM there are several channels and interfacing options that must be evaluated when integrating robotics and the corresponding fleet management systems.

Typically, robot platforms are integrated via OData APIs, EWM-WCU IDOC interface or via SOAP Webservices and RFCs. Further AGV, AMR and robots can be integrated using MFS over TCP/IP and telegram-based communication. You can find further information about available EWM interfaces and specific features and functions via the following links:

  • OData APIs for EWM: Find a list of available ODATA Services for EWM via SAP Help ‚Äì SAP S/4HANA - APIs for Warehousing or via the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.
  • EWM WCU IDoc Interface: Find a list of available IDocs for EWM via SAP Help ‚Äì SAP S/4HANA - Interface Between EWM and Non-SAP Systems.
  • SOAP Webservices for EWM: Find a list of available SOAP for EWM via SAP Help ‚Äì SAP S/4HANA - Enterprise Services in Extended Warehouse Management.

The choice of integration technology is largely driven by the robotics vendor (subsystem integrations), the partner solution, the need for end-to-end visibility, the types and primary functions of the robots involved (e.g., mobile, manipulation, or cognitive robots), and the size and heterogeneity of the fleet.

 With the blog post ‚ÄúThe SAP Extended Warehouse Management FAQ Series: Robotic Integration for EWM‚Äù we answer some of the most important and relevant questions of the topic of robotic integration to SAP EWM, such as which best-practice architecture is available for robotic integration, what is the typical required SAP EWM configuration, which partner solutions are available, what is the future of robotics integration, and much more.

 DAY 14: Reporting & KPIs with SAP EWM

 We have another guest article from Solution Advisory expert Andreas Rupp, covering KPI and reporting tools available for SAP EWM. Flexible, robust reporting is vital in warehouse logistics to meet the needs of everyone from floor staff to warehouse managers and logistics leads. SAP Extended Warehouse Management (SAP EWM) provides a comprehensive set of tools and frameworks to support operational, tactical, and strategic reporting. The tools available for warehouse reporting includes:

  • Warehouse Management Monitor - since its first release in 2005, the WM Monitor has been a central tool in SAP EWM for operational reporting. It enables real-time analysis and control of warehouse activities directly on the productive system.
  • EWM Measurement Services - introduced in 2007, the EWM Measurement Services provide a structured approach to defining and calculating warehouse KPIs.
  • Embedded Analytics with CDS Views - the introduction of SAP HANA Live in 2014 marked the beginning of embedded analytics in SAP EWM. Although HANA Live was later replaced by Core Data Services (CDS), CDS views offer significant advantages such as combining transportability with high performance and enabling complex data selections and calculations directly in the database.
  • SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) - enables real-time, cross-warehouse dashboards without data replication. EWM data can be combined with other sources for holistic insights.
  • Microsoft Excel Integration - with a small add-in, users can pull data directly from SAP EWM into Excel for further analysis‚Äîideal for organizations heavily reliant on Excel.

The blog post ‚ÄúSAP EWM Podcast Episode 18 - Reporting & KPIs with SAP EWM‚Äù summarizes the key reporting capabilities available for SAP EWM, and offers more information on these reporting tools, such as required activation steps, available customization options, KPI visualization tools, and much more. 

DAY 15: Meet the Expert Sessions

Today I would like to quickly share with a web channel where you might find videos on topics of interest. ‚ÄúA little something for everyone‚Äù as the saying goes. The Digital Logistics Webcasts hub stores the webinars of over 30 Meet the Expert sessions, which go in-depth into product releases, advanced functionalities and roadmap overviews. Here is but a sample for some of the latest content:

  • What¬¥s new: SAP Transportation Management 2025 FPS0 - SAP Transportation Management (TM) continues to evolve, and the 2025 FPS0 release is packed with innovations that redefine how intelligent transportation management operates. This enablement session is your gateway to understanding the latest capabilities, strategic roadmap, and how to unlock real value for your business.
  • What¬¥s new: SAP Extended Warehouse Management 2025 FPS0 - SAP Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) also received a plethora of updates in the 2025 FPS0 release, with innovations that redefine
    how intelligent warehousing operates. This enablement session is your gateway to understanding the latest capabilities, strategic roadmap, and how to unlock real value for your business.
  • Meet the expert: AI Features for SAP Extended Warehouse Management 2025 FPS0 ‚Äì this session cover the latest AI features made available in SAP EWM 2025 FPS0, such as the ability to talk to your warehouse via SAP Joule and a demo of AI-assisted predictive labor demand planning
  • Meet the expert: SAP Logistics Management Deep Dive ‚Äì as covered above in a previous Advent Day update, SAP Logistics Management is a new cloud-native solution recently released to the market. This enablement session is your gateway to understand the latest capabilities, strategic roadmap, and how to unlock real value for your business.

If you would like to register and access all of the 35+ archived webinars, or stay informed about upcoming ones, please access the Digital Logistics Webcasts page for details.

DAY 16: Warehouse Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition ‚Äì What‚Äôs New in 2025

In this day‚Äôs addition to the Advent blog post, I want to highlight some of the releases from our dear colleagues in the Warehouse Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition team, specifically the release blog posts from Christian Ries. Please find below some highlights.

With the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2502 release, SAP has delivered:

  • Lean Customer Returns - customers have been requesting us to also enable  Lean Customer Returns (BDD), since it is required for more special processes such as consignment pick-up as described in the process  Customer Consignment (1IU). With this release, such inbound deliveries can be received directly into Warehouse Management with document type Customer Returns Delivery (LR).
  • Outbound Delivery Order Split with Loading Completed - with 2408, the outbound delivery order split had been introduced, allowing customers to split items or handling units from an outbound delivery order into a new outbound delivery order. However, that feature came with the restriction, that Transportation Management was out of scope. With 2502, we have followed up on this and enabled the process to also work with Transportation Management. 

  • Mass Item Change in the App Manage Outbound Delivery Orders - warehouse clerks occasionally need to update multiple items of an outbound delivery order at once, for example because all items need to be staged to a different staging bay or a different door. Updating the delivery items with a mass change has now been enabled, making it much more convenient for the end user to perform these changes. 

In the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release, some of the highlights include:

  • Stock Removal Strategy for Direct Goods Movement Postings - some customers asked for a very simplified way of posting the consumption for the components of their production orders. Instead of using one of the production integration patterns where you first stage the components to the production supply area and then post the consumption from there, the staging and consumption is done in just one step. To simplify this process, we have introduced a new button in the app ‚ÄúPost Goods Movement‚Äù, to run the stock determination and to thereby propose the storage bin from which the consumption can be posted.

 

  • Compare Stock with Inventory Management - we have released a new app to compare the stock in Warehouse Management with Inventory Management. If there are any differences, then this app allows to immediately correct these differences with an additional stock posting, correcting the stock in Inventory Management. 
  • Migration Object: Assign Storage Bin to Production Supply Area - when working with the Advanced Production Integration, it is mandatory to maintain the assignment of storage bins to the production supply area, including the staging behaviour for individual products. As some of our customers have thousands of products to be maintained here, it is essential that this maintenance can be simplified with a migration object.
  • New CDS Views - there is a new CDS view to access the storage bin data, thereby making one of the most central objects available. In addition, there are new CDS views available in the area of wave management, providing access to wave headers and wave items but also to settings such as wave templates and wave types.

To read about these and all the other items of these releases, be sure to check out Christian‚Äôs articles linked above.

DAY 17: HU based backflush from PSA using Synchronous Posting

In today‚Äôs blog post update, I want to highlight a blog that gives guidance on how to manage Handling Unit based backflush from Production Supply Areas using Synchronous Postings.

In standard SAP, when you confirm production or process orders (CO11N/COR6N), call a BAPI/API, or use the Manage Production/Process Order apps, you‚Äôll see different batch selection behavior depending on whether the storage location is managed by EWM. For non‚ÄëEWM storage locations, batch determination follows the S/4HANA rules you‚Äôve configured (for example, FEFO or other LOBM criteria). For EWM‚Äëmanaged locations, however, the system does not apply those same S/4HANA batch determination rules ‚Äî it effectively defaults to FIFO based on goods receipt date and time, which can be confusing when MBC1 (261) conditions or CU70 sorting rules were expected to be used.

The reason is that SAP changed the batch determination logic for EWM‚Äëmanaged storage locations in synchronous scenarios. The system only considers sort fields that map to the /SCWM/S_STOCK_SORTED structure ‚Äî for example, WDATU_DATE (goods receipt date) and WDATU (goods receipt date and time). In practice, that means batch picking for locations relevant to Extended Warehouse Management follows the EWM sorting logic, which by default prioritizes goods receipt date to ensure consistent batch selection and processing.

If you need to align EWM behavior with your S/4 batch rules, you‚Äôll need to review the EWM sorting configuration and mapping to the /SCWM/S_STOCK_SORTED fields or adjust process flows so batch determination happens where your preferred logic is applied.

To find out which customization and process steps are needed to configure the HU based backflush from PSA using Synchronous Postings, please find all the details in the blog post ‚ÄúHU based backflush from PSA using Synchronous Posting - BAdI /SCWM/EX_EWM_GI_SORT_STOCK‚Äù.

DAY 18: Highlights of Transportation Management in SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition 2025

In the month of October, 2025, the release of SAP S/4HANA 2025 and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 delivered many innovations for SAP Transportation Management that further expanded its capabilities, strengthened the integration with SAP Extended Warehouse Management, provided more tools to ensure a Clean Core, and more. Some of the highlights of this release include:

  • Lean Service Procurement - the biggest advantage of working with Lean Service Procurement in TM is that freight charge invoicing is much more transparent, and invoice verification is simplified, reducing total operating costs. Now, charge items are displayed individually on the invoice. For the user responsible for checking invoices, it's much easier to validate the correctness of an incoming invoice against the calculated costs from TM because they can see all the charge items in the system and easily compare them with the individual items on an incoming (B2B or paper) invoice. The new lean service procurement introduces new apps for the accrual process. With these apps create and post accruals can be triggered after a certain status is reported in a freight execution document (e.g., checked out, departed, shipped on board, or uplifted). 

 

  • Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) in the Transportation Cockpit - in this release, we focused on the most important KPIs for road transportation and made them available for the freight order list, freight unit stages, and truck resources.  In total, we deliver 93 standard KPIs from various categories, such as Utilization, Quantity (weight, volume, etc.), Distance, Duration, CO2 emissions, Costs
  • TM based Scheduling for Stock Transport Orders using Business Process Scheduling - we introduced TM-based scheduling for sales orders with S/4HANA 2023. With this release, we introduced TM-based scheduling using Business Process Scheduling for Stock Transport Orders as well. Similar to sales order integration, the scheduling can be even used if the stock transport order is not integrated with TM after the document is saved.
  • Global Trade Service (GTS) Integration: Update Export declaration after initial declaration - in the past, if there were changes to a freight order or container, the customs declaration had to be canceled, and a new export declaration was required. This is no longer necessary, as it‚Äôs now possible to update an initial export declaration with changed information, since GTS can work with updated information from TM.
  • Simplified Multimodal Booking for Shippers - simplified freight booking for ocean and air was already available on the public cloud. It provides a user interface (UI) and process that is closer to the LE-TRA process, offering stage-specific invoicing to carriers. Along with the simplified UI comes the ability to determine a valid agreement for all carriers, as well as the respective charge calculation for multiple carriers. The follow-on processes in settlement, such as the new lean service procurement integration, are also supported. This simplified UI, with fewer buttons and fields, is now available to private cloud customers through the correct web dynpro application configuration assignment to the booking type.
  • Integration to Product Compliance: Mixed loading checks - the mixed loading check has been added to the TM execution document checks. During the document check, all items relevant to Product Compliance are checked to see if they can be transported together. Unlike the current DG classic check, if items are physically separated (e.g., in a truck and trailer or in different containers), the document will no longer be blocked from execution. Also, the mixed loading check considers product loading incompatibilities during freight unit building. Furthermore, during VSR optimization, mixed-loading incompatibilities are considered, and items may be planned on separate freight orders. Lastly, mixed-loading incompatibilities are considered during load consolidation. Consequently, incompatible products are planned into different containers.

If you want to learn more details about the above highlights, or learn what else was delivered with this release for SAP Transportation Management, please check out the blog post ‚ÄúHighlights of Transportation Management in SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition 2025‚Äù.

DAY 19: Goods Receipt Reversal for External Procurement in EWM - SAP S/4HANA 2025

Here I would like to highlight an article dealing with a new Warehouse Management Monitor method made available with the SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS00 release. As of SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS0, the Warehouse Management Monitor added a new "Reverse after Putaway" method that makes reversing a goods receipt for an inbound delivery (e.g., a purchase order) possible even after the putaway warehouse task has been confirmed. This change gives warehouse teams greater flexibility: if an error is discovered later ‚Äî for example during picking ‚Äî they can trigger a goods receipt reversal at any time, provided the related purchase documents are still available in the system (not archived). For a detailed breakdown on how to cancel the Goods Receipt after Final Putaway for External Procurement in Extended Warehouse Management, the process steps for testing, as well as an overview of potential errors and current limitations, please read the article by Adam Tamer ‚ÄúGoods Receipt Reversal for External Procurement in EWM - SAP S/4HANA 2025‚Äù.

DAY 20: Highlights of Extended Warehouse Management in SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition 2025

The SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS00 release also brought a range of updates and innovations for SAP Extended Warehouse Management, where we further expand the AI capabilities available for SAP EWM, add in more functionalities and scenarios for the Advanced Shipping & Receiving integration, deliver a host of extensibility and user experience improvements, improve the Quality Management and Production integrations, and much more. Below you can find some of the highlights:

  • Predictive Labor Demand Planning update - with the SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS03 release, we delivered the foundation of predictive labor demand planning (LDP) that we‚Äôve been able to predict planned workload on Outbound Delivery Order and Warehouse Order/Warehouse Task level based on historical data collected from RF Picking and Packing activities. With this release, you can now use machine learning empowered workload forecast to anticipate future labor needs for better operational planning and resource allocation. The solution uses a minimum of 3 weeks of historical data and predicts the short-term labor demand in next days or weeks. 

  • Cross-Delivery Handling Units - you can now use cross-delivery handling units (HUs) in the outbound process with Advanced Shipping and Receiving. The deliveries that are packed together must fulfill several conditions. The system runs the checks when you set the status of the delivery to Ready for Shipping, or in the case of immediate loading, when you set the status of the HUs to Packed for Shipping.
  • Harmonized Outbound Delivery Update in Logistics Execution - we ensured that the changes in Logistic Execution process are harmonized across ERP Logistics Execution (LE), Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) and Transportation Management (TM). For example, you can change specific values of an outbound delivery in LE after the outbound delivery is distributed to EWM. Any changes you make in LE outbound delivery are automatically distributed to EWM and TM.
  • Partial Goods Issue for Component Consumption & COGI split - if you use synchronous goods movements for the consumption of components by manufacturing, you can split the goods issue for components consumed from EWM-managed storage locations if less than the full quantity needed is available on the production staging area (PSA). The system posts the goods issue for the available quantities and posts the remaining quantity to the Reprocess Goods Movements app (COGI). This feature is only available in embedded EWM.

 

  • Reverse Goods Receipt after Final Putaway for Stock from External Procurement - you can also reverse goods receipt for stock from external procurement even after final putaway. The reversal is available in the warehouse monitor, as the Reverse after Putaway method in the nodes for physical stocks, for example, Stock and Bin > Physical Stock. You can also use the API interface /SCWM/IF_API_RVS_STOCK_PTWY in a custom development to perform the reversal. If you are using decentralized SAP Extended Warehouse Management for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition, and your processes use Logistics Execution (LE) deliveries, you must set the Control Process: Extended Reversal After Final Putaway field to Allow for Completed LE Delivery in Customizing for Extended Warehouse Management under Interfaces > ERP Integration > ERP Integration for Decentralized EWM > Set Control Parameters for ERP Version Control.

To see more details on the above-mentioned topics as well as see what other enhancements we delivered with this release, I highly encourage you to read the blog post ‚ÄúSAP Extended Warehouse Management for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition, 2025 FPS00 ‚Äì What‚Äôs New‚Äù or explore our latest ‚ÄúSAP Extended Warehouse Management for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition‚Äù slide deck.

DAY 21: SAP Extended Warehouse Management, Private Cloud Edition ‚Äì Essential Knowledge Base, Learnings and Tools

Over the recent months and years, the SAP EWM Product Management team have tried to consolidate as many informational and learning resources as possible. To that end, we have revamped our SAP Community page with many useful links, related pages, blog posts, How-to guides, product release reports, and more.

However, as the list of such resources can grow, it can become a bit cumbersome to search and navigate to the most essential documentations. For example, you may be looking for page that has the most recent product updates, or you need to learn where you can get some further learning and knowledge to better prepare yourself for potential customer implementation projects.

To that end, we decided to take things a step further, and prepare this blog post in order to compile (according to our estimates) the most essential informational and learning content that a new reader could use to get up to date on our product. This blog post will be continuously updated, as well will take in feedback for further additions and improvements, as well as add in the latest L1 and What‚Äôs New product release resources as they become available.

As this article will be continuously updated, I encourage you to bookmark the page with the article ‚ÄúSAP Extended Warehouse Management, Private Cloud Edition ‚Äì Essential Knowledge Base, Learnings and Tools‚Äù in order to check up periodically on any updates.

DAY 22: Transportation Management in SAP S/4HANA, Private Cloud Edition ‚Äì Essential Knowledge Base, Learnings and Tools

Similar to the SAP EWM blog post, SAP Transportation Management also has an article that covers all of the most essential knowledge base, tools and guides to get your SAP Transportation Management projects running. I highly encourage you bookmark Holger Wittmer‚Äôs compilation blog post, as it is continuously updated, based on the feedback we receive for further additions and improvements on a regular base, as they become available. For example, we recently updated it to offer a Learning section ‚Äì a new Open SAP Course targeting Advanced Shipping & Receiving will be offered in the Essential Knowledge base. Keep following the page ‚ÄúTransportation Management in SAP S/4HANA, Private Cloud Edition ‚Äì Essential Knowledge Base, Learnings and Tools‚Äù to stay updated on all thing relevant for SAP Transportation Management.

entry.title: SAP EWM Labor Management (Engineered Labor Standards)
entry.content:
SAP EWM Labor Management is designed to help warehouses gain clear visibility into how efficiently work is performed on the floor. It enables businesses to define labor standards, track planned versus actual execution times, and measure processor performance for different warehouse activities. These standards can be based on various operational parameters such as weight, quantity, product attributes, or activity type, allowing flexible modeling of real-world scenarios. The functionality also supports tracking of both direct tasks and indirect labor efforts, giving a complete picture of workforce utilization. This blog focuses on demonstrating how engineering labor standards work within SAP EWM.

Configurations

1. Activate BC Sets:

T.code: SCPR20

To enable SAP EWM Labor Management (LM) functionality, SAP provides several LM-specific BC Sets. These BC Sets deliver predefined configuration content that supports various LM capabilities such as activity definitions, engineered labor standards, exception codes, performance measurement, and warehouse-level settings.

  • /SCWM/LM
  • /SCWM/LM_ACTIVITY
  • /SCWM/LM_ELS
  • /SCWM/LM_EXCEPTION_CODES
  • /SCWM/LM_EXTERNAL_PROCESS_STEPS
  • /SCWM/LM_NR_EPD
  • /SCWM/LM_NR_INDIRECT_LABOR_TASK
  • /SCWM/LM_PLAN_AREA
  • /SCWM/LM_PREPROCESSING
  • /SCWM/LM_WHS_NUMBER
  • /SCWM/PRC_LM_10
  • /SCWM/PRC_LM_15

2. Activate Labor Management
Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Activate Labor Management

3. Define External Process steps

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Define External Process Steps

 

4. Assign External Process steps to warehouse Activity

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Assign External Process Step to Warehouse Activity

5.   Assign Planned Activity Areas

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Assign Planning Activity Areas

6. Define Number Range for Performance Document

Path : SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Define Number Range for Performance Document

7. Define Delivery Date/Time for Preprocessing

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Define Delivery Date/Time for Preprocessing

8. Activate Change Documents in Labor Management

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Activate Change Documents in Labor Management

  • Activate Change Documents for Processor

  • Activate Change Documents for Performance Document

  • Activate Change Documents for Time and Attendance

9. Define Processor Types

Path : SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Processors -> Define Processor Types

10. Define Reporting Groups for Processors

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Processors -> Define Reporting Groups for Processors

11. Define Work Categories

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Processors -> Define Work Categories

12. Define Capacity Variants

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Shift Management -> Define Capacity Variants

13. Maintain Shift Management Defaults

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Shift Management -> Maintain Shift Management Defaults



14. Create a Processor

T.Code: /N/SCMB/PRR1

15. Assign User to BP created

16. Conditions for Engineered Labor Standards

T.code: /N/SCWM/LM_CE

17. Formula for Engineered Labor Standards

18. Determine Engineering Labor Standards

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Determine Engineered Labor Standards

Test :

Pre- requisites:
Create two deliveries and distribute them to EWM, ensuring each delivery has a different weight, one below 20 kg and one above 20 kg, to match the conditions we configured.

Let‚Äôs first take an example with a weight below 20 kg, execute it, and review the workload. After that, we‚Äôll do the same for a case above 20 kg.

Maintain Inbound Deliveries

T.code: /N/SCWM/PRDI

As you can see, the delivery mentioned above includes a handling unit weighing 4.400 kg. Let‚Äôs create the warehouse task for unloading and execute it through the RF screen to validate the processor‚Äôs performance.

Let‚Äôs create a warehouse Task using Monitor-

T.code: /N/SCWM/PRDI>> Inbound Delivery>>Follow on Functions>>Warehouse Task

By clicking ‚ÄúCreate,‚Äù the system generates a warehouse task to move the handling unit from the Door to the GR-ZONE (staging area). Next, let‚Äôs review the Warehouse Order for ‚ÄúLM Active.‚Äù As shown, the LM Active checkbox is enabled, indicating that Labor Management is activated for this step.

Now let‚Äôs execute the activity in RF screen
Path: Inbound>> Unloading>> Unload by Delivery

Upon scanning the HU, the system captures the start timestamp and initiates the timer to measure the total time taken by the associate or processor to complete the activity.

Once you scan the destination bin and confirm ‚ÄúYes‚Äù for Completely Unloaded, the timer stops. Now let‚Äôs review the workload in the monitor.

The screenshot above is from the workload monitor, which displays the execution details. As shown, the processor ‚ÄúNICK WILDE‚Äù executed the unloading task, with the recorded weight of 4.2 kg. The planned execution time is 5 minutes, which is a critical value derived from the condition and formula maintained in configuration steps 16 and 17.

The monitor also shows the actual execution details start and end timestamps, planned duration, and the actual duration taken by the processor. In this example, the processor took 7.467 minutes to complete the task, compared to the planned 5 minutes. Based on this variance, the system calculated the processor‚Äôs efficiency as 66.96%.

Now, let‚Äôs take another delivery with a weight of 42.200 kg and review how the system determines the planned execution time for unloading, using the same configuration rules from steps 16 and 17.

Let‚Äôs execute the step and find out the performance

After execution, the planned time is 7 minutes, calculated based on the configured formula. The actual duration recorded is 18.317 minutes, resulting in an efficiency of 38.22%, since the processor took significantly longer than the planned time.

Through these scenarios, we validated how SAP EWM Labor Management calculates planned, actual, and efficient metrics using condition-based formulas. By executing unloading tasks for deliveries below and above the 20 kg threshold, we observed how the system dynamically derives planned execution time and evaluates processor performance via RF-driven timestamps. Importantly, these calculations are not limited to weight alone any relevant operational parameter (such as quantity, HU type, product group, packaging material, distance, activity type, or process step) can be incorporated into the condition and formula framework.

This flexibility allows organizations to tailor labor standards to real-world warehouse processes. Overall, these examples demonstrate how workload monitoring offers clear visibility into performance, highlights gaps between planned and actual durations, and enables data-driven optimization of warehouse efficiency in SAP EWM.

entry.title: The Future of Supply Chain Management | Part 5 of 6
entry.content:
Supply Chain 2035: The New Era of Logistics: AI and Robotics in Action?

Part 5 of the ‚ÄúSupply Chain of the Future‚Äù series focuses on transportation and warehouse logistics where speed, reliability, and transparency determine costs, service, and resilience. The joint study by SAP Business Consulting and K√ºhne Logistics University clearly shows that companies who tightly integrate their processes digitally can prevent bottlenecks, reduce costs, and increase service levels. At the same time, however, the survey also makes it clear that the ambitions of many companies in the field of transport and warehouse logistics for 2035 are surprising ‚Äì less because the technologies are lacking, but because their implementation is difficult alongside current operational challenges.

Global competitive pressure is increasing, and the pressure to act in terms of efficiency and cost optimization remains high. Energy, transport and staff are becoming more expensive, growth stimuli in the industrial sector are scarce in many developed countries, and efficiency is no longer achieved incidentally. Even small improvements in lead times, utilization, or error rates have an immediate impact on delivery dates and costs. In manufacturing companies, logistics is the backbone of stable processes, and standstill is therefore not an option. At the same time, the shortage of skilled workers often exacerbates the pressure to act: In Germany and other countries, jobs in warehouses and transport are increasingly difficult to fill, especially where processes are still lived manually and fragmented.

Tasks must be solved differently in the future ‚Äì through higher automation, targeted assistance systems, the use of AI, and the courageous rethinking of processes. Against the backdrop of increased pressure to act, the results of a survey conducted in April 2025 show a mixed picture: 39 percent of respondents expect significantly stronger digitalization and data-driven warehouse processes with significant advances in responsiveness and transparency by 2035. 28 percent expect the use of advanced technologies such as autonomous vehicles or drones in transport and material flow scenarios; another 28 percent see AI agents as integral support tools for dispatchers, warehouse managers and drivers. In addition, 20 percent expect connected ecosystems with real-time data exchange across company boundaries. So, the direction is clear, but expectations seem moderate compared to the technological perspectives and already existing use cases. One of the possible reasons: the vision exists, but there is often a lack of clear implementation plans, as time, know-how and resources are scarce. Many companies are lagging behind with the modernization of their processes and systems and can therefore integrate the potential of innovative technologies and real-time data into their daily work and decision-making to the required extent.

At the same time, the survey reveals weaknesses in the current situation: Only 17 percent of the 180 surveyed companies use real-time data comprehensively to optimize warehousing. Only 9 percent are committed to real-time transparency in the transportation sector with accurate arrival time forecasts, and only 6 percent have established collaborative planning and execution models with partners. It is positive to mention that 19% of companies have already gained initial experience with generative AI ‚Äì so this is a new field where progress has been made. Overall, however, the figures show that the comprehensive implementation of digital innovations in practice still falls significantly short of the possibilities.

What needs to be done? Successful innovation requires a clear, prioritized strategy and readiness to adapt processes and technologies, supported by comprehensive and high-quality data, intelligent analytics, and effective orchestration. On the one hand, a resilient digital backbone which integrates process and sensor data into a consistent situational picture across transport, yard and warehouse is required. Orchestration within the company as well as data exchange across company boundaries is crucial. This data forms the basis for AI-driven decision logic, such as predictive ETA forecasts, dynamic capacity and slot controls, and anomaly detection. AI agents should perform routine tasks, structure exceptions, and provide appropriate options for action. In addition, AI technologies are increasingly moving into physical logistics processes, where many experts expect further groundbreaking developments ‚Äì both in the software and hardware sectors. This includes increasingly flexible robots and cobots paired with innovative business models (e.g., renting robots to flexibly absorb seasonal peaks). Fast integration and the ability to up- and downscale these solutions within existing systems are crucial.

To achieve the transition to innovative technologies and processes, it is essential to proactively address cultural resistance and implement effective change management. To drive innovation at every level of the business, leaders must deliver a holistic vision and actively involve employees in the change process. An open communication culture and continuous training of employees help to create a positive environment in which technological innovations are accepted.

Why do ambitions remain subdued? Many companies are running multiple transformation projects at the same time. Logistics is still often seen as a pure cost center and shifts backwards in priority ‚Äì although it often delivers quick and measurable effects. The first step to systematically unlocking this potential can be, for example, to develop an innovation roadmap, depending on the business context. This identifies clear areas of action and bottlenecks and links business goals with the appropriate technology choice: not only ‚ÄúWhich robot?‚Äù, but ‚ÄúWhat problem, which flow, which bottleneck ‚Äì and which measure scales across locations?".

Our appeal: start now rather than catch up too late. The technologies are up and running, there is a need for action, and market pressure is increasing. Understanding the implementation as a continuous process with a clear roadmap, iterative scaling, and measurable effects closes the gap between ambition and reality ‚Äì and transforms logistics from an often more reactive element of the value chain into a strategic advantage.

Figure: Vision 2035 and Reality 2025 in Transportation and Logistics

 

This article was written in collaboration with Prof. Kai Hoberg (K√ºhne Logistics University) in the context of the SAP-KLU study "The Supply Chain of the Future‚Äù.

entry.title: Streamlining Manufacturing Logistics with clean core API‚Äôs
entry.content:
In the rapidly moving world of manufacturing logistics, agility and minimizing complexity is crucial. SAP S/4HANA for Manufacturing Logistics, with its latest API updates, is supporting this pace:

  • Clean Core Approach:
    • Separates extensions and integrations from core processes
    • Reduces total cost of ownership (TCO) and improves agility
    • Enables integration with analytics and cloud services

 

  • Why?
    • Faster decision-making and simpler upgrades
    • Better operational efficiency and long-term resilience
    • Continuous business value delivery

The updated APIs fully align with our Clean Core principles, offering robust solutions that improve integration, automation, and competitiveness. These innovations can genuinely transform how you run your manufacturing logistics operations.

Lets double click into it!

We delivered three API‚Äôs to run Route Trains and Shuttles, including an API to get access to your Shuttle configurations.

 

Route Train Operations:

The route train enhances logistics by handling not only production supply but also tasks like inbound processes and various replenishment processes, ensuring efficient, effective and flexible operations.

Streamline your logistics with Route Train Operations (A2X)! This powerful API integrates external applications to optimize loading and unloading processes in warehouses and production environments. Here‚Äôs what makes it a must-have:

  • Effortless Warehouse Validation: Log on or off warehouse resources and verify their readiness with ease.
  • Simplified Recovery Case Checks: Stay informed about the recovery status of your warehouse resources.
  • Streamlined Tour Management: Create system-guided tours to simplify loading and unloading workflows.
  • Smart Handling of Units (HUs): Validate, load, or remove HUs during tours seamlessly and efficiently.
  • Pause or Continue Operations: Flexibly interrupt or resume loading/unloading workflows whenever needed.
  • Customizable Tour Stops: Skip, transfer, or tailor stops by stop type (e.g., PSA or Transfer Point) to match your requirements.
  • Instant Storage Bin Insights: Check which bins are empty for smarter space utilization.
  • Complete Unloading Capability: Unload all handling units quickly and without issue.
  • Detailed Metadata Access: Retrieve vital data on loading, unloading, tour stops, and handling unit compositions for complete control.

Whether you‚Äôre optimizing warehouse workflows or streamlining production logistics, the Route Train Operations API is here to improve efficiency.

 

 

 

Shuttle Operations:

The shuttle simplifies the movement of goods between locations, like from a production plant to a shipping warehouse, using trucks, trains, or other transportation, while combining storage and warehouse processes under one EWM warehouse number, without needing separate inbound or outbound deliveries.

Simplify your shuttle logistics with Shuttle Operator (A2X)!

This API integrates external applications to optimize loading and unloading processes for shuttles in manufacturing and warehouse environments. Here‚Äôs how it makes operations seamless:

  • Create New Shuttles with Ease: Set up new shuttles to streamline transportation in just a few steps.
  • Retrieve Location or Carrier Information: Access key information about your shuttle whenever needed.
  • Add or Remove Loading/Unloading Points: Gain full control by easily adding or removing points for logistics flexibility.
  • Smart Handling Unit (HU) Operations: Load, unload, or transfer multiple HUs (or Freight Units) to and from shuttles without a hitch.
  • Access Detailed Consignment and Cargo Data: Read consignment information to ensure accuracy in handling cargo.
  • Update Shuttle Status: Choose from critical status options like "Start loading," "Start unloading," or "Complete," ensuring workflow alignment.
  • Manage Seals for Freight Security: View, create, or remove seals on shuttles for better security and compliance management.
  • Gain Metadata Insights: Retrieve essential service metadata for enhanced logistics visibility.

From efficient shuttle creation to secure handling of cargo, Shuttle Operator (A2X) equips you with everything needed to run smooth and reliable transportation operations. Try it now and take control of your logistics!

 

 

 

Shuttle configurations:

Optimize your shuttle logistics configuration with Shuttle Configuration (A2X)! This API is designed to enhance shuttle loading and unloading workflows by providing essential transport and carrier data. Here‚Äôs how it can help you stay ahead:

  • Retrieve Transport Details for Shuttles: Access specific information on the means of transport for shuttle logistics, making planning and tracking effortless.
  • Access Carrier Information: Instantly retrieve carrier details to ensure smooth coordination between vendors and logistics teams.

With Shuttle Configuration (A2X), you gain quick access to essential configuration data, laying the foundation for efficient shuttle operations. Ready to integrate smarter workflows into your logistics? Try it today!

 

 

 

What‚Äôs Possible with Manufacturing Logistics APIs

Clean Core APIs enable you to build innovative and custom solutions for logistics and warehouse management by leveraging SAP‚Äôs modern architecture. From SDK apps, to MDK Apps, providing modern FIORI apps and integrate automation, here's what you can achieve:

  • Build Custom Native Apps: Design tailored Android or iOS apps for seamless consumer grad User Experience 

     

 

  • Create SAP Fiori/UI5 Applications: Develop SAP-based applications for guided loading/unloading processes and workflow tracking with responsive designs.
  • Integrate External Applications or Robotics: Connect Manufacturing Logistics APIs with third-party tools for transportation management or warehouse systems.

 

  • Automate Operational Workflows: Streamline processes like shuttle configuration updates, tour adjustments, and metadata retrieval with API-driven automation.

 

  • Enable Cross-Platform Solutions: Develop solutions that work across web, desktop, tablets, and mobile devices, ensuring maximum flexibility.

These APIs empower your teams to innovate while keeping the SAP core clean, scalable, and future-proof.
