entry.title: How to Modify Standard SLED using a BAdI- VB_SLED_MANAGEMENT
entry.content:
Synopsis- There should some functionality either to influence( change) the Shelf Life Expiry Date( SLED) or Remaining shelf life in some exceptional cases, primarily in Consumer based industry.

Requirement- Recently working with Food Processing company, we were tasked to reduce SLED by some N days after standard calculation. The business involves Finished goods produced as 'Fresh' but its latter converted into new Product Called as 'Fresh as Frozen'. In this process of product conversion, Mat 2 Mat transfer(Fresh to Fresh as Frozen), a new SLED is also calculated for target material on the day of posting. Primarily, SLED of new product has to be reduced by 2 Days.

Solution- Since the core of the solution was built on custom RF( Using /SCWM/POST and some Idea from MIGO( WM Packing) New screen), we called a BAdI VB_SLED_MANAGEMENT. Basically the BAdI VB_SLED_MANAGEMENT is meant to change the process parameters in the shelf life expiration handling. The SLED of a material is changed during the goods movement posting process( Mvt Type) called inside the BAdI.

Badi has the method MAINTAIN_SLED_PARAMETERS allows to change all the relevant parameters of shelf life expiration date processing for goods movements.

Using this, the SLED parameters of the material master can be changed.

  • Total shelf life (C_MHDHB)

  • Remaining shelf life (C_MHDRZ)

  • Period indicator (C_IPRKZ_HBD/C_IPRKZ_RLZ)

  • Rounding rule (C_RDMHD)

The two additional parameters C_HSDAT and C_VFDAT allow changes to the contents of dialog fields Date of manufacture (DM07M-HSDAT_INPUT) and Shelf life expiration date (DM07M-VFDAT_INPUT).In below example, BAdI was called in custom RF( Which also had Batch Creation Bapi along with Mat 2 Mat conversion logic with HU creation)

Once Material 2 Material transfer is triggered, batch was created with reduced SLED( Minus 2 days from Standard calculation)

Date of Production= 04.12.2025

Total Shelf Life=16 days

Stnd SLED= 04.12.2025+ 16= 20.12.2025

Revised SLED by BAdI= 20.12.2025- 2= 18.12.2025( The offset days is maintained TVARV at Material group level)

All changes are recorded in Batch master.

CALC and CCHECK can be changed as required in method MAINTAIN_SLED_PARAMETERS (for example 'Check only' => C_CALC = SPACE, C_CHECK = 'X'). We used Plant +Mvt Type to stop the recalculation of SLED by passing C_CALC=SPACE as other plants should not be impacted with this change.

Please read all the documentation of BAdI mentioned in documentation carefully before implementing it.

entry.title: SAP EWM Layout oriented storage control (LOSC) behind the scenes
entry.content:
In SAP EWM space, LOSC feature plays an important role in every project. This blog will help you to understand the background logic with scenario specific understanding.  It is bit technical so don't be overwhelmed , I've tried to explain in simple terms. Hope it helps. Enjoy the blog .üôÇ

Scenario 1: Product WT creation from  /SCWM/ADPROD or against WHR with full with drawl.  No pick point check in source storage type


Configuration:

Source Storage type:

LOSC:

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Execution:

Product WT create

 

 

 

 

 

 

Note: This scenario behaves the same way if your rounding rule is '5' where we round to the multiple of available stock in this case at HU level & it matches the requested pick quantity.

 

 

 

 

 

Debug mode:

We can  see  the  main  program on the top  and  also in the call stack.

The FM is /SCWM/ROUTING_LAYOUT_CHECK   is mainly to check for LOSC.


 

 

 

 

 

Inside the FM we can see the highlighted code which checks
1. IV_FLGHUTO ( HU WT flag) 

2.  IV_HOMVE ( Important field for LOSC* we will see this further)

3. LS_VT331-PPNTA ( Pick point field in source storage type)

If any of the above fields are having value then it will eventually go to the main LOSC determination FM /SCWM/TROUTL/DET

which will check the entry from LOSC config settings shown above.

We see the IV_HOMVE is coming with value 'A' which then eventually checked and updated LV_HOMVE with 'C'

 

 

 

 

 

So, the question is how this IV_HOMVE is getting the values. ü§î

Let's go 1 step back in debugging to get the answer.

This is coming from the  below FM '/SCWM/TO_SRC_HU_HOMOGEN_SET'

called inside the FM /SCWM/REM_BIN_DET_INT üòá

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

If we see now inside the FM we can see that system checks what is the WT quantity (CS_LTAP-VSOLM) ,100 KG as shown below

and is it matching with the HU quantity (LV_QUANTITY) ,100  KG as shown below.

If yes, then it will eventually pass CS_LTAP-MOVEHU with value 'A' and then CS_LTAP-HOMVE is  marked  'X'

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

So far, we have these values,

but if you recall IV_HOMVE value inside the FM /SCWM/ROUTING_LAYOUT_CHECK  was 'A' not 'X'.  Therefore, we still need to see where this value is being updated. 
Here it is 

 

 

 

 

 

Note: You can notice here, CS_LTAP- MOVEHU value is passed into IV_HOMVE not CS_LTAP-HOMVE.

Now if we continue, we can see that it finds the LOSC settings ,

finally we will  have 2 WT's- 1 HU WT (open) and waiting product WT.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Scenario 2: Product WT creation from /SCWM/ADPROD or against WHR with partial quantity. 

No pick point check in source storage type

 

 

 

 

In this case the requested quantity 10 KG (CS_LTAP-VSOLM) is not matching with full HU quantity 100 KG (LV_QUANTITY)

therefore the value will not be set & code will return in the below FM /SCWM/TO_SRC_HU_HOMOGEN_SET

 

 

 

 

This will eventually not qualify for LOSC. Skipping the main LOSC FM.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Finally creating only 1 Product WT.

 

 


Scenario 3 : The storage type have pick point active and we have HOMVE ( whole HU) A for partial and C for complete HU pick scenario.

Configuration:

Source Storage type:

 

 

LOSC:

 

 

Execution:

a. Product WT creation for partial picking-

 

 

 

 

 

Debug Mode:

As pick point flag is active it will  always be going into the FM /SCWM/TROUTL_DET  via  /SCWM/ROUTING_LAYOUT_CHECK.

IV_HOMVE is initial, so it is passing 'A' into LV_HOMVE

 

 

 

 

It found the LOSC entry with IV_HOMVE ='A'

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Finally creating 2 WT's- 1 active HU WT and 1 waiting product  WT

 

 

Similarly, lets see the complete HU pick case.

b. Product WT creation for complete HU picking.

The LOSC will find the correct entry with HOMVE ='C' and create the tasks.

 

 

 

 

Debug mode:

We can see that system has found LOSC searching with HOMVE value 'C'


 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Again, created 2 WT-s , 1 active HU WT and waiting product WT.


 

This concludes the blog. Thanks for reading and do share your comments.


Disclaimer:  Above logic is tested in demo systems but actual project scenarios might be different so please do the required due-diligence.


Best Regards,

Y K B B Rudra Narayan

entry.title: Warehouse Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 Release ‚Äì What‚Äôs New
entry.content:
Core Function 

Enablement of Additional End-to-End Processes 

Following our Suite-First strategy, we consider it essential that Warehouse Management works with all scope items and process variations that are available within SAP ‚Äì and as you might know, that is quite a lot. Therefore, I am happy to share that with this release we were able to release the enablement of six (!) additional end-to-end processes: 

  • Stock transfer with delivery (BME) in combination with transportation management 
    • Intercompany stock transfer returns (2TS) 
      • Intracompany stock transfer returns 
        • Customer returns for sales kits (5CX) 
          • In-house repair (3XK) - Send back to customer 
            • Just-in-time supply to customer (2EM) - Summarized JIT calls 

              For all of these, the respective delivery can now be distributed to and processed in Warehouse Management. The selection of the delivery via the according reference documents is enabled, e.g. to select an outbound delivery based on the JIT reference. You‚Äôll find more details on each of these in the linked What‚Äôs New presentation. 

              Stock Removal Strategy for Direct Goods Movement Postings

              In my view, this innovation is quite special, because it is different from the classical paradigm to always go via warehouse tasks when removing stock. Some customers asked for a very simplified way of posting the consumption for the components of their production orders. Instead of using one of the production integration patterns where you first stage the components to the production supply area and then post the consumption from there, the staging and consumption is done in just one step. This is achieved, by posting the consumption directly from the storage bin in the warehouse. The operator is then responsible to physically remove it from there and hand it over to production, but from a system perspective the stock is already consumed. To simplify this process, we have introduced a new button in the app ‚ÄúPost Goods Movement‚Äù, to run the stock determination and to thereby propose the storage bin from which the consumption can be posted.



              Combined Picking in RF 

              This feature has already been very popular in Private Cloud EWM and has now been asked for by many of our Public Cloud customers. The scenario is to have multiple outbound deliveries, all requesting the same product. A typical scenario would be e-commerce where many different end customers have ordered one piece of a certain product. Since a picking warehouse task is always created per outbound delivery order item, this would mean in this scenario, that multiple picking warehouse tasks are created, all requesting one piece of the same product from the same storage bin. Obviously, confirming those in RF on the mobile handheld device one-by-one is quite cumbersome for the warehouse operative and very inefficient. With this innovation, those quantities are now combined, summed up and displayed as just one pick in RF, while in the background, it is still individual warehouse tasks. To prevent a day-one impact, this feature must be activated in the configuration. 


               Updating Media

              Migration Object: Assign Storage Bin to Production Supply Area   

              Even though this innovation is ‚Äújust‚Äù a migration object, I am convinced that it is very important to many customers. When working with the Advanced Production Integration, it is mandatory to maintain the assignment of storage bins to the production supply area, including the staging behaviour for individual products. As some of our customers have thousands of products to be maintained here, it is essential that this maintenance can be simplified with a migration object.

              Compare Stock with Inventory Management 

              When using Warehouse Management, the stock is managed in the warehouse on individual storage bins, but the stock is also still managed in Inventory Management on storage location level. Warehouse Management is then the leading system in terms of stock management. All stock postings are done in Warehouse Management, but they always update Inventory Management. Therefore, the stock balance in Warehouse Management and Inventory Management is always in sync. In rare cases it can happen that deviations occur, for example because of rounding issues. Worst case, this can then lead to an error when trying to update Inventory Management from Warehouse Management. Therefore, we have released a new app to compare the stock in Warehouse Management with Inventory Management. If there are any differences, then this app allows to immediately correct these differences with an additional stock posting, correcting the stock in Inventory Management. 

              Extensibility 

              New CDS Views 

              Same as with the last releases, we have again shipped additional CDS views, allowing customers to access the data they need to build their extensions. 

              There is a new CDS view to access the storage bin data, thereby making one of the most central objects available. In addition, there are new CDS views available in the area of wave management, providing access to wave headers and wave items but also to settings such as wave templates and wave types. 

               

              Integration 

              Additions to the Warehouse Order and Task API 

              With the Warehouse Order and Task API being one of the most central APIs in Warehouse Management, it has received some additions in this release: 

              • Merging multiple warehouse orders into one warehouse order 
                • Splitting warehouse tasks from an existing warehouse order 
                  • A new parameter to prevent the full handling unit withdrawal during the confirmation of product warehouse tasks.

                    Additions to the Storage Bin API 

                    The Storage Bin API had been a read-only API so far but has now been enhanced with the following: 

                    • Create storage bins 
                      • Update storage bins 
                        • Action to block storage bins 
                          • Action to unblock storage bins 

                            FIND OUT MORE! 

                            This blog only pointed out some of the highlights of this release ‚Äì you can find the full list of innovations in the What‚Äôs New presentation.

entry.title: SAP EWM Podcast - Episode 25 - SAP's new Solution SAP Logistics Management
entry.content:
Welcome to our blog post for the SAP EWM Podcast Episode 25 ‚Äì SAP's new Solution SAP Logistics Management. You can listen to the podcast episode in English and in German on Spotify, Amazon Music, Apple Podcasts or Sway! Enjoy!

SAP Logistics Management: Filling the Gap Between Simplicity and Complexity

When it comes to warehouse management, SAP Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) has long been the go-to solution for large, complex operations. From massive spare parts warehouses to production supply chains, EWM delivers the depth and sophistication needed to handle demanding logistics environments. But what about the smaller, simpler warehouses? Surprisingly, analysts estimate that nearly one-third of warehouses worldwide are still managed with paper or spreadsheets. For these businesses, EWM can feel overwhelming‚Äîtoo powerful for their needs, too complex for a quick rollout.

This is where SAP‚Äôs new solution comes in: SAP Logistics Management.

Why a New Solution?

SAP EWM covers complexity levels 3 to 5, where automation, industry-specific processes, and advanced services are essential. Many customers desire a simplified solution for warehouses of Levels 1 and 2 warehouses ‚Äî those with basic functions and minimal automation. SAP Logistics Management is designed to offer a streamlined, accessible solution for smaller warehouses or satellite locations that don‚Äôt require the full scope of EWM.

More than just Warehouse Management!

While warehouse processes are at the heart of Logistics Management, the solution goes further:

  • Transport Management: The solution focuses on dispatching and it supports scenarios like parcel shipping, less-than-truckload (LTL & direct LTL), and no shipping (e.g. customer self-pickup for Ex-Works). Full truckload (FTL) capabilities are on the roadmap.

  • Network Integration: Logistics Management connects warehouse and transport processes into a broader logistics ecosystem, ensuring seamless coordination.

 

SAP Logistics Management combines Warehouse Logistics, Transportation Logistics and Network Logistics

This combination makes it more than just a ‚Äúlightweight warehouse tool.‚Äù It‚Äôs a unified logistics platform for companies with simple needs today but ambitions to grow tomorrow.

Who Benefits?

SAP Logistics Management is tailored for:

  • Smaller businesses with straightforward logistics processes.

  • Large enterprises managing multiple small or satellite warehouses alongside their main EWM-driven hubs.

  • Companies focused on transport first, such as those replacing legacy solutions like WM/Stock Room Management or LE-TRA, with the option to add warehouse functionality later.

Completing the Portfolio

SAP already offers a reduced version of EWM in the SAP Cloud ERP , but that solution is integrated only. SAP Logistics Management expands the portfolio by providing a decentralized option that can connect to other ERP systems, including SAP Cloud ERP Private or even SAP ECC. This flexibility ensures that SAP can now support logistics operations across the full spectrum‚Äîfrom paper-based warehouses just starting their digital journey to highly automated global distribution centers.

 

Technical Integration and Future Capabilities

SAP Logistics Management fills the gap between complex and simple warehouses. But complexity isn‚Äôt defined only by warehouse size ‚Äî it‚Äôs also about the software requirements. Logistics Management is a full-fledged Warehouse Management System (WMS): it manages storage bins, inbound and outbound processes, deliveries, inventory counts, and more. So how does the technical integration actually work?

Decentralized Architecture

SAP Logistics Management is designed as a decentralized solution. This means it connects to ERP systems via interfaces rather than being embedded directly. Key aspects include:

  • Master data integration: Materials and business partners are transferred, with batch data coming soon.

  • Transactional data: Purchase orders and deliveries are imported via APIs and transformed into ‚ÄúLogistical Demands‚Äù‚Äîthe core documents Logistics Management operates on.

  • Future expansion: Additional ERP documents such as inbound deliveries, customer orders, stock transfers, production orders, and returns will be integrated over time.

ERP Integration Focus

  • Initial focus is on S/4HANA Private Cloud integration.

  • S/4HANA Public Cloud connectivity is planned for Q3 2026.

  • Integration runs through the SAP Integration Suite, ensuring standardized and scalable connectivity.

Functional Scope at First Release

The first general availability release in February 2026 will already cover a wide range of features. However, some capabilities will follow shortly after e.g. Batch management is planned to be available in Q1 2026.  Serial numbers are not yet supported at launch, though the inventory model is technically prepared for them. Compared to EWM or TM, Logistics Management will initially have fewer advanced features. But as a true Public Cloud product, it benefits from continuous innovation: new functionalities are delivered every two weeks, without waiting for rigid release cycles.
You can find more information in the SAP Logistics Management Product Documentation. 

AI Support with Joule

A standout feature is the integration of SAP Joule, the AI Copilot. This makes the system easier to learn and use. Users can ask natural-language questions like ‚ÄúHelp me create a storage bin‚Äù or ‚ÄúShow me today‚Äôs deliveries.‚Äù No need to memorize transaction codes‚Äîthe AI assistant guides users through everyday tasks

SAP Logistics Management Home Screen powered by Joule

 

Cloud Extensibility and SAP BTP Foundation

SAP Logistics Management isn‚Äôt just about simplifying warehouse operations‚Äîit‚Äôs also about embracing the Public Cloud mindset. With new interfaces, extensibility options, and a modern architecture, the solution is designed to evolve rapidly while keeping costs and complexity under control.

Extensibility in the Cloud

Flexibility is essential in logistics. SAP Logistics Management plans to offer several ways to extend functionality:

  • APIs: Starting in 2026, SAP will release APIs to enable deeper integration and customization.

  • Key-User Extensibility: This extensibility option is also planned for 2026 and will enable customers to add fields not available in the standard system for example - a familiar feature from SAP‚Äôs public cloud portfolio.

  • Label and List Customization: Layouts for loading lists and labels can already be adjusted, including adding company logos.

Unlike traditional systems, customers no longer access database tables directly (no SE16 or manual SELECT statements). Instead, extensions are handled through APIs, ensuring a Clean Core. This approach makes the bi-weekly updates possible without disrupting customer systems.

Built on SAP BTP

SAP Logistics Management is developed on the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), similar to other new solutions like Digital Manufacturing (DM). This has several advantages:

  • Lightweight provisioning: Setting up a Logistics Management instance takes minutes, not hours.

  • Cost efficiency: Running outside the full S/4HANA stack reduces overhead.

  • Continuous innovation: New features are delivered every two weeks. They remain inactive until customers choose to enable them which ensures stable operations of the solution. This model ensures customers benefit from rapid innovation without the burden of constant regression testing.

SAP Logistics Management is not the successor of SAP EWM or SAP TM

A common question is whether SAP Logistics Management replaces EWM (Extended Warehouse Management) or TM (Transportation Management). The answer is clear: No. 
Logistics Management focuses on simpler warehouses and transport scenarios, not large distribution centers or multimodal transport networks. SAP EWM and SAP TM continue to evolve. The recent S/4HANA 2025 release introduced new features, and the roadmap is full of enhancements for future releases. 

SAP‚Äôs strategy is complementary: SAP Logistics Management fills the gap for smaller, decentralized operations, while SAP EWM and SAP TM remain the backbone for complex, large-scale logistics.

A New Path for Warehousing and Transport

For retail customers with large distribution centers and complex material flow systems (MFS), the choice is clear: SAP Extended Warehouse Management (EWM). Likewise, when transport requirements involve multiple modes of transportation or advanced features like route optimization and driver planning, the answer is equally straightforward: SAP Transportation Management (TM).

But many of these same customers also operate smaller warehouses or have simpler transport needs. In these cases, the new SAP Logistics Management (LGM) solution may be the perfect fit.

Imagine a ‚Äúpop-up‚Äù warehouse rented temporarily to handle seasonal demand or additional capacity. With Logistics Management, such a site can be up and running quickly, without the complexity of a full EWM implementation.

 Key Takeaways

From SAP‚Äôs perspective, the most important points about Logistics Management are:

  • SAP Logistics Management does not replace SAP EWM and SAP TM.

  • Fast and cost-effective implementation is a core strength.

  • Modern user interfaces with full Joule/AI support make the system intuitive.

  • Continuous innovation ensures new features are delivered regularly.

A New Journey in the Public Cloud

SAP Logistics Management marks the beginning of a new journey for warehouse and transport solutions. Every journey starts with a first step‚Äîand that step has now been taken. 

With its focus on simplicity, speed, and innovation, Logistics Management promises to be an exciting and successful addition to SAP‚Äôs logistics portfolio, complementing SAP EWM and  SAP TM rather than replacing them.
